subsubtopic: ESTABLISHMENT OF ROYAL COMMISSION INTO PRICING PRACTICES
speechtext:
That this House urges the government to launch a royal commission into pricing practices in the pharmaceutical industry to determine the rate of mark-ups in price at each transaction, from manufacturer to wholesaler or distributor, from wholesaler or distributor to retailer, and from retailer to the public, in order to determine how such mark-ups affect the Canadian consumer.
He said: Mr. Speaker, first of all, I would like to explain why I presented this motion.

This motion has a very clear purpose which I hope will meet and satisfy not only the curiosity but the political interest of my colleagues in this Chamber.
The background is the following. First, the pharmaceutical industry in Canada is a substantial business. Its activities amount to some $4.5 billion every year.
Second, for certain products called patent drugs, the industry enjoys a substantial monopoly situation which could be strengthened and amplified if the present negotiations at GATT are successful. On that subject my colleague for York West will be intervening later.
Third, the whole question of mark-ups in the price of pharmaceutical products affects the consumer.
Finally, mark-ups in this industry also affect the taxpayer and the public purse.
For all these reasons I would like to present the following case which is based on a meeting held last May by the Liberal task force on the industrialization and economic renewal in Ontario. It took place here on the Hill with representatives of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association of Canada.
On that occasion, we learned that according to the data at hand with the representatives of the association, the mark-ups are as follows: the one practised at the manufacturing level ranges between 15 and 60 per cent. As well there is apparently an inventory charge at the factory level of approximately 10 per cent. When the product leaves the factory gates and reaches the wholesaler, the mark-up at that point is anywhere between 7 and 10 per cent. When the product reaches the pharmacist, the mark-up is anywhere between 30 and 50 per cent, we were told, and to that, of course, is added the dispensing fee. The dispensing fee varies from province to province and ranges from $6 per dispensation to $11.
Why is this a public issue? It is a public issue in two respects. This is an industry that is federally regulated and, as you may recall, the last and rather intensive debate which took place in this House was on Bill C-22.
Second, the cost of prescription drugs is covered by provincial health care plans with public funds. The beneficiaries or the people who are covered by this provincial health care plan, will be mostly found among senior citizens and low income Canadians and Canadians who are under hospital care and who receive medical treatment and drugs while in hospital.
While it is not possible for me to indicate the precise amount of drug costs involved for these two major categories, I would be inclined to suggest that it is a fairly substantial sum.
Mr. Speaker, as a result of this brief overview you can see why the public purse is heavily affected by the mark-ups and by the cost of drugs.
Under the Ontario drug benefit plan, for instance, we learned that over the past decade the increase in expenditures has been 12 per cent for every year. That is

February 10, 1992
Private Members' Business
not a minor increase year by year in expenditures by the Ontario drug benefit plan.
The Manitoba minister of health and welfare, when he appeared in 1988 before the Senate committee on banking, trade and commerce, said that the expenditures on drugs in Manitoba were increasing at that time at the rate of 15 per cent per year. It is worth while noting that by contrast, while the drug costs are increasing over 10 per cent per year according to the data made available by Ontario and Manitoba, in the case of Ontario the hospital expenditures as an over-all figure have risen only by 4.5 per cent per year. So you can see that the percentage increase year to year in the cost of drugs is three times as high as the percentage of increase in the over-all hospital expenditures.
The House may recall, and I made a brief reference to this fact, that we had quite an intensive discussion at the time of the amendments to the Patent Act and under Bill C-22. The present law makes a provision for a review board to monitor drug prices. At this point you may want to ask, Mr. Speaker, why should we have a royal commission as proposed in this motion? In answer to that question I have to draw your attention to the fact that the mandate of the review board is considerably limited. It is limited to reviewing the price at which the manufacturer sells to the wholesaler. The review board has no authority to review the final price or mark-ups between the factory gate and the store shelf, so that reviewing the annual price increases of patented drugs takes place at that very factory gate snap shut situation, not at the level of the wholesaler, not at the level of the pharmacist, at the retail level.
In addition, and this was also the object of interesting discussions in the Senate, the review board can only review but not roll back prices. In other words, the board cannot determine whether the consumer has been given a fair shake or fair treatment.
For all of these reasons, a royal commission on drug pricing in Canada becomes a necessary step. It becomes a must if we want to give Canadians the assurance that they are treated fairly in the process of acquiring drugs at the retail level.
Let me review again the mark-ups because it is important. At the manufacturers' level, the mark-up is between 15 per cent and 60 per cent. In addition to that, there is an inventory charge of some 10 per cent. Once the product leaves the factory gate, the wholesaler's mark-up is between 7 per cent and 10 per cent. Once it reaches the pharmacist, the mark-up is between 30 per cent and 50 per cent. In addition to that, the pharmacist, for the task which consists of counting a certain number of tablets, typing a label which indicates the name of the patient and the general name of the drug, but which does not, however, reveal the content of it and that is a very serious shortcoming, I submit to you, charges a fee that ranges between $6 and $11 per prescription.
So it becomes clear that we must look at this pattern of mark-ups. They have to be confirmed, have to be examined, have to be studied. That will be the purpose of the commission, to compare them, to look at the mandate given to the review board, which we will find does not protect the consumer. The consumer is helpless because the review board is not empowered to do anything about most of the steps from the factory gate to the consumer.
It is true that it can look at the prices at the factory gate, but even there, where it has jurisdiction to review, it has no jurisdiction to roll back. So, Mr. Speaker, to make this intervention as short as possible and allow as many colleagues as possible to intervene, I will conclude by saying that the motion before you, in essence, asks for fairness in the settling of drug prices for Canadians.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
subsubtopic: ESTABLISHMENT OF ROYAL COMMISSION INTO PRICING PRACTICES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise in my place today to respond to the motion from the hon. member for Davenport.
It was recommended that the government establish a royal commission on the pricing practices of the pharmaceutical industry.
I know that the hon. member is motivated by a genuine concern for the impact the drug prices have on consumers, and I know that he is concerned about the ability of provincial governments to respond to increasing prices.
February 10, 1992

As much as we can acknowledge the undoubted good intentions of this motion, I am afraid that the motion for a royal commission is misplaced.
Any royal commission, as we know, imposes a large expense on the public treasury. Clearly there are important issues which must be examined by commissions of inquiry, but if we are going to burden the taxpayer with the expense, first we had better make sure that we genuinely do need a commission.
I am afraid that when one looks at the proposal and at the state of the pharmaceutical industry in general, I cannot see that we should inflict upon taxpayers the cost of this kind of study.
To begin with, several items the hon. member would like to examine fall under provincial jurisdiction. I am sure that it was not the intention of the hon. member for Davenport to intrude on provincial responsibilities for pharmaceutical price controls at the retail level, but that is the effect of his motion.
In fact, hon. members are well aware that the provinces have demonstrated a great concern for drug pricing. The challenges vary from province to province.
Each province is more capable of focusing on its own needs than a federal inquiry would be. In fact, some provinces have recognized their own responsibility to investigate these matters.
Both Ontario and British Columbia have already conducted their own commissions into the areas that fall under their jurisdiction. I am certain that no one in this House would endorse a commission that would only duplicate that work.
Any federal inquiry would inevitably get bogged down into the complexities of provincial systems over which this House has no jurisdiction whatsoever.
The issue of provincial responsibilities brings me to another reason why I believe this House should vote against this motion.
Hon. members from both sides are no doubt aware that the minister of health and welfare is committed to working with the provinces to ensure reasonably priced drugs for Canadians. In fact, the minister met with his provincial counterparts on January 27 to discuss this matter and other issues of mutual concern.
Private Members' Business
I am reassured by the commitment of the Minister of National Health and Welfare that prices will be kept reasonable for consumers, and I am encouraged by his efforts to work with the provinces on the issue.
At the federal level, we have the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board. Since the Patent Act was amended in 1987, the board, regardless of any limits on its mandate, has kept price increases for patented drugs below the increase in the Consumer Price Index. The board will be given enhanced powers to keep prices of patented drugs reasonable.
At the same time that this government is working with the provinces to ensure reasonable drug prices, it is working to encourage more research and development in the Canadian pharmaceutical industry.
There have already been some remarkable results. Glaxo Canada, one of the largest research-based pharmaceutical companies in Canada announced on January 16 that it was moving ahead with plans to build a $70 million manufacturing plant in Mississauga.
Glaxo estimates that it will invest $275 million over the next five years on research and development. In 1991, the company invested $25 million in research and development and has doubled its employment over the past five years to more than 1,000 employees across the country.
Four days after the Glaxo announcement, Astra Pharma Incorporated said it was considering building a new $150 million research facility in Mississauga, creating about 50 new research jobs.
Astra is already committed to an R and D investment in Canada of about $95 million over a five-year period. Further investment in facilities and equipment at the company's Mississauga location is likely to reach $97 million.
Both commitments are expected to result in about 160 new jobs. At the same time Astra announced that it has rolled back the 1992 prices on its prescription drugs to the 1991 level. The price reduction would amount to about 4 per cent or 5 per cent on the company's prescription drugs.
At a time when the world-wide pharmaceutical industry is evolving quickly Canada must strive to play an important role in the growth of this industry.

February 10,1992
Private Members' Business
As we can see, new research means high-paying skilled jobs for the medical and scientific communities. New research means a more competitive Canadian pharmaceutical industry. New research means new products that will add to the comfort and health of Canadians.
Canadians want and deserve more research and development leading to better medicines and treatment.
We want to send a signal that Canada welcomes the investment that means jobs in the pharmaceutical industry. We want our intellectual property protection to be an incentive for investment.
I would like to remind the House that investment by the brand name pharmaceutical industry has increased substantially since patent protection was improved in 1987.
At that time the industry made a commitment to increase research and development expenditures to 8 per cent of sales by the end of 1991. Has the innovative pharmaceutical sector lived up to that commitment? Not only have they lived up to the commitment, they have surpassed it.
By the end of 1990, a year earlier than their commitment called for, the research and development to sales ratio of patent holders had risen to 8.8 per cent.
That is a substantial increase from the 4.9 per cent research and development to sales ratio which the industry exhibited before the act was amended. Total research and development has increased from $165.7 million in 1988 to $281.3 million in 1990.
We have come a long way in encouraging research and development investment in the Canadian pharmaceutical industry, but we can do more.
That is why the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs recently endorsed multilateral trade proposals to strengthen patent protection for pharmaceuticals.
These proposals are contained in the draft text of the GATT agreement. They would allow pharmaceutical patent owners to enjoy the full term of protection now provided to patent owners in all other sectors of our economy.
Increased patent protection in Canada will bring increased medical research and development to Canada. This means new jobs and a more prosperous competitive Canadian pharmaceutical industry.
At the same time the generic industry must continue to play an important role in providing medicines to Canadians. The government is sensitive to the needs of the generic industry in adapting to the new pharmaceutical policy.
I remind the House that under the current system a drug typically enters the market 10 years after its patent is filed and the generic copy can enter seven years later.
The current GATT text that we have endorsed would add another three years to this period. In other words the generic products would come on the market after 20 years rather than after 17.
Generic drug manufacturers in Canada use competitive manufacturing technology to produce a broad line of drug products. This segment of the industry is expected to grow at a reasonable rate, in part because of a number of successful drugs that are coming to the end of their market exclusivity in Canada.
The generic drug manufacturers will be able to continue to produce drugs under their existing compulsory licences. Under the proposed changes to the patent protection announced in January they will still be able to market drugs once patents have expired.
In summary, first, the government has stated that if changes are made to the Patent Act it will grant new and enhanced powers to the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board.
Second, the government is consulting with the provinces to ensure drug costs are kept reasonable.
Third, the brand name pharmaceutical companies have stated that they would increase their level of R and D in Canada and their performance bears it out.
What would the effect of a royal commission be on this progress? We have all been in political life long enough to know the effect that commissions of inquiry have on work in progress. It is either slowed or stopped. The temptation is to place things on hold until the results of a commission are known.
Those are the reasons that I would urge the House not to support the well-intentioned motion before us.

February 10, 1992

subsubtopic: ESTABLISHMENT OF ROYAL COMMISSION INTO PRICING PRACTICES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me say from the outset that I compliment my colleague, the member of Parliament for Davenport for putting forth this motion.
In terms of the drug pricing practices and policies, it is not only substantively well placed, but the timing could not have been better.
That is why I fully support the intent of the motion before the House of Commons for debate.
I say the timing could not be better because on January 14 the Minister for International Trade on behalf of the Canadian government basically agreed to a proposal put forth at the GATT negotiations in Geneva to grant and give brand name pharmaceutical companies essentially a 20-year monopoly on new drugs.
As you well know, Mr. Speaker, the existing legislation in Canada allows for a seven to ten-year protection for brand name drugs and allows at the same time a generic industry that has grown, flourished and matured and has become an integral part of the Canadian health care system to become a reality.
I think the move by the Minister for International Trade will seriously injure, if not completely undermine, that Canadian generic industry which essentially is a made-in-Canada for Canadians system that I think Canadians at large are indeed proud of.
We have to face the reality that we have to strike a balance between the large foreign multinational pharmaceutical companies and those generic companies in Canada when in fact 92 per cent of the pharmaceutical activity in this country is foreign owned. We have to take stock when we throw statistics out that indeed there are some 3,000 jobs involved in the generic industry, largely in Ontario but certainly also in western Canada and other places across the country. We simply cannot throw that to the wind.
When we talk about the generic industry, clearly Toronto, my home city, is a very leading part of that equation where we have the two largest generic industries in Canada, namely Novo Pharm and Apotex.
When we talk about the effect of that January 14 decision, it is clearly twofold. On the one hand, it has a very serious economic impact on the 3,000 jobs that I have just talked about in terms of stopping any further
Private Members' Business
research, all in Canada I might add, by our generic industry. It will stop any contemplated expansions. For instance, Apotex and Novo Pharm are in the mood to expand. Apotex was to have a $50 million research project going on in Winnipeg, Manitoba, which is now seriously in jeopardy. Clearly there is an economic impact in terms of jobs. Lord knows that we need each and every one of those 3,000 jobs, particularly as Canada and Canadians are gripped in one of the worst recessions that this country has ever faced.
The second impact of that impending decision is the whole question of the cost of drugs to Canadians. The government simply has to face, rather than ignore, that the generic industry and generic drugs have permitted a competitive and stabilizing force regarding the price of drugs.
The speaker who preceded me talked about the need for having a competitive pharmaceutical industry. It is quite ironic that a government member should be saying that the effect of the January 14 decision would not be to encourage greater competition, but would place on firmer ground the whole question of giving these multinationals a very large monopoly.
The fact that drug pricing has been moderated by the generic industry is an integral part of our health care system, whether the government likes it or whether it does not. We have to be cognizant that those prices will rise under a state of monopoly. It is natural. Governments and hospitals are now faced with spiralling health care costs. In my province the hospital association is requesting of the Government of Ontario some $600 million only to cover the debts incurred over the last number of years. St. Michael's Hospital, a leading hospital in Toronto, has to close departments because of financial constraints. This is not the time to be giving foreign multinational corporations a monopoly. I am not talking about stopping them at the border. Not at all. I think we should welcome that investment.
I am saying that there has to be a balance between those foreign multinational corporations which wish to invest and hopefully create some economic prosperity in this country. We also have to balance that with the generic drug industries that have helped keep prices down rather than increasing through the roof.

February 10, 1992
Private Members' Business
In addition to hospitals and governments, the individuals, our citizens, our consumers are also facing a very tough economic time. They are trying to hold on to their jobs or they are trying to get a job. It has really come down to two basic interests to Canadians, having a job and a livelihood and also trying to have protection for their health and an accessible, affordable system with which to do it.
At this time individuals cannot bear increased prices for their medicines. Are those who do not have a job and who become sick and those on fixed incomes and pensioners who have been granted a 75 cent a month increase on their pensions going to accept a 20 year monopoly on brand name drugs? Is this government not sensitive to the fact that in the last two to three years any new drug introduced on to the market has been incredibly expensive? On average 100 tablets costs between $100 and $200. Are we not to say that there is room for moderate influence? Are we not also prepared to say that a brand name pharmaceutical company should enjoy some protection on their research and development for discovering that drug? On average, that pharmaceutical company gets its money back after only two to three years. Therefore, a 10-year protection would seem to be plenty of time to get back those research moneys and also make a profit. But why 20 years?
In fact, if you think about the life of a drug, it is not going to be more than 20 years. Because of technology and research, after a drug has been on the market for 20 years there will be new discoveries. The generic industry coming in after 20 years is probably not going to be very lucrative or encouraging. After a 20-year life of that drug, rather than the generics replacing it there will be a new and improved brand name drug. Therefore, there really will be a monopoly on those drugs and through monopolies there will be an uncontrollable price on these drugs. The government has not spoken to how it will ensure fairness in that system.
Last, how were Canadians consulted? Did Canadians give the green light to the Minister for International Trade on January 14 to move on what has been an integral part of our health care system? In fact, I have a copy of a letter to the president of Apotex, Barry Sherman, dated Friday, January 10, from the government saying that it wished to consult. After one working day, on Tuesday, January 14, the Minister for International Trade chipped in and gave in on the generic drug licensing system in this country.
I say that is not consultation. Canadians have not been consulted. I am saying to you, Mr. Speaker, through this motion presented by the member for Davenport, that our health care system in this country helps to define what this country is all about, gives expression to the term "Canadianism" and Canadians will not let go of that very lightly. Therefore, the pricing of drugs in this country is a going concern and deserves the support of this House to put in practice the essence of the motion before us.

speakerposition: Chief Government Whip's assistant; Deputy Whip of the Progressive Conservative Party
subsubtopic: ESTABLISHMENT OF ROYAL COMMISSION INTO PRICING PRACTICES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on November 22, the hon. member for Davenport raised the matter of drug prices in the House. He presented a motion, urging the government to launch a royal commission of inquiry into pricing practices in the pharmaceutical industry. Although I agree that the price of drugs in Canada deserves our special attention, with due respect for the hon. member, I wonder whether the current situation in the pharmaceutical industry is such that we need a royal commission of inquiry.
The Canadian government is not in the habit of starting this kind of process without good reason. In fact, a thorough analysis was carried out by the Commission of Inquiry on the Pharmaceutical Industry just seven years ago, in February 1985. Furthermore, since 1987, the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board, a regulatory agency with quasi-judicial powers, has a mandate to ensure that the prices of patented drugs are kept at reasonable levels.
Mr. Speaker, I wonder whether before putting his motion before the House, the hon. member took the time to read the board's latest annual report. According to the report for the year ended December 31, 1990, and I quote:
The prices of patented drugs generally complied with the board's
guidelines, which take into account the Consumer Price Index.
As far as I know, the situation has not changed drastically since then. I may remind hon. members that between December 1987 and December 1990, the average annual increase in the price of patented drugs was
3.1	per cent, while the average annual inflation rate was 4.7 per cent.
February 10, 1992

A preliminary review of 152 new drugs examined by the board in 1990 showed that for 100 of the drugs, companies had followed the guidelines on introductory prices for new patented drugs which came into effect in January 1990. The prices of 16 of the 52 remaining products were approved later on, either because the price had gone down or the change in price level was sufficiently below the cumulative change in the Consumer Price Index for the 1990 price to comply with the guidelines.
Review, verification of data and discussions with patentees are progressing for the remainder, according to the board's annual report. The current situation in the pharmaceutical industry has improved since the act to amend the Patent Act came into force in 1987.
At the time, there were some very gloomy predictions about the repercussions of this bill on the price of drug products. However, as reflected in the report of the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board, the pessimists were wrong. The pharmaceutical industry kept its word, as predicted by the Hon. Harvie Andre, then Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs.
On December 16, 1986, Mr. Andre told the legislative committee on Bill C-22, and I quote:
That improved patent protection would lead to an increase in
research and development in the Canadian pharmaceutical industry.
Spending on research and development throughout the industry rose from $165.7 million in 1988 to $281.3 million in 1990. In other words, the ratio of research and development to sales revenue increased from 6.1 per cent in 1988 to 8.8 per cent in 1990.
All this goes to prove that the amendments to the Patent Act passed in 1987 have benefited Canada and, as a result, all Canadians. Research and development in the industry has expanded faster than was expected. At the same time, consumers have been protected against unreasonable increases in the price of patented drugs.
On the eve of further changes arising from multilateral trade proposals made at the GATT talks, changes that will strengthen patent protection for pharmaceutical products, the Canadian government has promised to ensure that the prices of patented drugs will remain reasonable for Canadian consumers. It is important for
Private Members' Business
Canada's competitiveness and prosperity that our country should adopt a position that is in harmony with the multilateral proposals.
The new protection measures contained in the GATT agreement are one of the ways in which Canada can reinforce its position in the international market. We must remember that this is a market that puts a premium on research and innovation. While Canada must protect consumers, it must also transform its economy, which is now based mainly on the extraction and export of natural resources.
Canada must get in tune with a world economy based on value-added products. The pharmaceutical industry is very promising in this regard. It is therefore important for Canada to implement a legislative framework that favours basic research so as to provide for the creation and manufacture in Canada of innovative value-added products and also products that can be exported.
The present situation must be improved. Prosperity is not assured. We have seen countries lose their prosperity in a short time and that must not happen in Canada, Mr. Speaker. We have everything it takes to meet the productivity challenge. What is important now is that we be aware of the main problems, that we have the will to act and especially that we be prepared to implement a legislative framework for economic prosperity in Canada.
I think that the pharmaceutical industry is a good example of the kind of turnaround that must be achieved in all Canadian industries to ensure prosperity and maintain Canada's competitiveness in the world economy. Since changes were made to the Patent Act in 1987, the pharmaceutical industry's current expenditures on basic research have increased significantly. They rose from $53.5 million in 1989 to $70.1 million in 1990, an increase of 30.9 per cent.
The Patented Medicine Prices Review Board reported that in 1990, 47.5 per cent of current spending on research and development was in Quebec. In addition to investments, many jobs have been created since 1987, including 195 in research and development. It must be pointed out here that increasing basic research in Canada means definite benefits for Canada's health system and well-paying employment for science graduates from

February 10, 1992
Private Members' Business
our Canadian universities, not to mention the marketing of innovative new products internationally.
A country like ours, where a quarter of production and a third of employment depends on exports, must follow the main trends of the world economy. I am thinking in particular of the very rapid evolution of technology. Companies that can take advantage of it can increase their productivity. They can also make better products more quickly and at lower cost.
In this regard also, the Canadian pharmaceutical industry is a leader and Canada must therefore encourage its development at the same time as it protects consumers. Personally, Mr. Speaker, I am convinced that the mechanisms now in place in our Canadian system allow for consumer protection and will also enable our federal and provincial governments to benefit from the availability of drugs at very competitive prices.
I do not believe that it would be appropriate to launch an inquiry at this time.

subsubtopic: ESTABLISHMENT OF ROYAL COMMISSION INTO PRICING PRACTICES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is with pleasure that I rise to respond to the motion of my colleague, Motion No. 617, which urges the House to launch a royal commission into pricing practices of the pharmaceutical industry.
This is a very important issue and it does respond to the government's recent announcement of extending patent protection to the large brand name drug manufacturers in this country.
This will be to the detriment of the business of the generic drug industry which is represented in Ontario by two firms, Apotex and Novopharm.
I speak to this issue from an aspect of morality. Governments are very much influenced by the strength of various lobbies that address them, but too seldom do we address the morality issues. By extending patent protection to companies and by not following the advice of the motion put forward by my colleague we are not looking at the more important issue of accessibility of the public to much needed drug therapy.
By extending protection we are making drug therapy more expensive. We have seen that in the reduction of the number of drugs that are on the list of the province
of Ontario, for example. Because of the high costs of pharmaceuticals the government has had to strike off the list certain very beneficial drugs. This is not a benefit to us as a country. It relates very directly to our health care system as a whole.
The emphasis today is often on the distribution and the provision of aggressive high-tech but very expensive medical technology to people at the expense of preventive medicine which would benefit our whole country in reduced health care costs. It would certainly benefit far more individuals than our present system.
Obviously, from the many reports we have heard, our present system is under great stress and could falter because of the very high cost types of procedures we are having to support at the moment without reflection. My colleague's motion proposes that we set up a royal commission to review this. I do not accept the government's proposition that this motion is intruding into the provincial realm. It is a federal issue as well. We have the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board which is a federal board, but we are saying that we need to take a special look at this very important issue and set up a royal commission which I endorse whole-heartedly.
I also come to this issue from a different perspective, that is the perspective of the international community, Third World countries in particular. I was involved in trying to bring health care to Third World countries. I can tell the House that it was the generic firms of this country which provided the very necessary assistance, not the brand name pharmaceutical companies. Companies like Apotex and Novopharm assisted by providing thousands and thousands of doses of free medication, the most broadly used and very good quality medication, to people of our world, not just our country, who were most in need of therapeutic pharmaceuticals.
It distresses me that as we increase patent legislation and extend the patents to brand name companies, companies such as Apotex and Novopharm are forced to reduce expansion of their industry. This has a ripple effect of being very damaging, destructive and punitive to not only the many Canadians who need low price drugs but to the millions and millions of people who live in the Third World and can benefit from the generic drugs.
February 10, 1992

We have to review, revise and relook at our whole health system. One component of it that is very important is the pharmaceutical sector of therapy. We must decide how we can best serve in justice and equality the needs of all Canadians rather than put an emphasis on the very exclusive small sector of high-technology at the expense of pharmaceutical needs.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (for the President of the Treasury Board) moved
speechtext: that Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada, be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee H.

speakeroldname: Mr. Bill Kempling (Parliamentary Secretary to President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank the President of the Treasury Board, the hon. member for Quebec, for the opportunity to speak about Bill C-26, the Public Service reform act.
Doing research for this second reading speech gave me the opportunity to examine in some detail the recent history of the Canadian federal Public Service and to make up my own mind about how efficiently the Public Service is delivering programs and services, and what areas need to be improved.
I must say the more I learned, the more I found that I was like the majority of Canadians, and I dare say some members of this House: when it comes to real knowledge about the Government of Canada we are somewhat lacking in facts and possessed of unfortunate negative
Government Orders
stereotypes about the men and women who work here. We do not know enough about our own public servants is what I am saying. You know what I mean when you even think this way yourself. There are three persistent misconceptions about public servants held by many Canadians.
Contrary to popular myth, public servants or civil servants are not all overpaid and underworked. They do not have life-long jobs, nor do they all work in an unstressed environment out of touch with reality. Contrary to popular myth, most of them do not just push paper all day. They care about the citizens they serve. And, again contrary to popular myth, Public Service waste and mismanagement is not largely responsible for the huge federal debt. While cutting red tape and making the Public Service more business-like is very important, it will not solve most of the country's budgetary problems.
In 1992 anyone who believes these myths is just plain wrong.
The federal Public Service is a vital national institution in the process of renewing itself from within and becoming more business-like in almost every respect. What is more, every Canadian has a stake in the success or the failure of this effort. Survey results compiled last year by a research team from Carleton University, the University of Ottawa and the University of Western Ontario found that federal public servants are hard working, stressed out and want substantial changes in how they perform their jobs. After years of budget cuts, downsizing, stalled careers, workload increases and non-inflationary pay increases culminating in a salary freeze this year, federal employees, clients and knowledgeable outsiders are calling for major changes in how the Public Service operates.
The changes are under way. The initiative to reform the Public Service was begun some two years ago under the banner Public Service 2000. Public Service 2000 has proved to be very well named. The name denotes a vision of the future while the fact that it was announced in 1990 and not in 1999 is an acknowledgement that many of the changes needed, including changes in attitudes, will take some time.
The Public Service has a long and splendid history. While 1992 marks the 125th anniversary of Canada as a nation, I would remind hon. members that 1992 also

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
marks the 125th anniversary of the federal Public Service as an ongoing institution. While there is no perfect way to go about reforming such a huge, complex or historic institution, I think remarkable progress has been made to date, progress that is largely unknown to members of this House and I daresay to most taxpayers who may be beginning to notice an improvement in service from employees.
Shortly after Public Service 2000 was announced, 10 task forces set off to look closely at specific areas that they felt to be in need of reform. The task forces undertook a great deal of consultation, especially in the area of service to the public, which I am sure all hon. members would agree must be the raison d'etre of the Public Service.
The task force reports were all made public. The reports contained some 300 recommendations. The reports and the feedback they generated, plus advice from academics and clients, resulted in a white paper which was tabled in this House more than a year ago by the hon. President of the Treasury Board. The white paper outlined many areas of needed change.
As a result of the white paper, where legislative changes were not required, many administrative reforms have already been put in place or are in the works.
Central agencies are taking the lead in slashing red tape and time consuming reporting requirements. They are moving away from a prescriptive controlled oriented approach to one more focused on results that are achieved by providing guidance and advice to departments and instituting clear accountability mechanisms.
The Public Service is now clearly more important to the federal government than the preservation of the systems and structures. Departments, in turn, are also eliminating their own internal administrative constraints where they have served to reduce efficiency unnecessarily-
Over and above the Public Service 2000, six straight years of frozen operating budgets for almost all departments, coupled with five straight years of downsizing, have forced departments to cut administrative overhead and channel resources elsewhere in order to maintain their programs in the face of ever growing demands.
Frontline employees are now being empowered to make decisions about service delivery. At the more senior levels, layers of management have been trimmed back to only three below the deputy minister, speeding up decision making and empowering the rest of the employees. This restructuring and empowering is especially important for regions as employees no longer have to check it out with Ottawa every time. They can use their own common sense and good judgment to help Canadians faster. They can spend more time listening to clients, understanding their needs and providing the services they are responsible for instead of filling out forms and adhering to restrictive procedures. In other words, employees are now spending less time serving systems and more time serving citizens, and this benefits every Canadian taxpayer.
On another very important front, the government remains committed to finding the most effective ways of delivering its programs. Recently the government regained through negotiations with all of its unions the right of management to decide how best to deliver programs to Canadians. The full range of program delivery options is again available, including delivery of programs by the government itself or by some other method, including privatization, contracting out work, devolving some functions to other levels of government, or performing them through special operating agencies.
Operating budgets are already being introduced in some departments so that management can decide on its own what are the most efficient mixes of resources, be they human or financial, to deliver the programs that Parliament has agreed should be delivered. Most of the costs of providing programs and services are being recovered under a user fee policy that identifies the program beneficiaries who may not be paying an appropriate share of the costs. Examples include services in areas of transportation, passports and various forms of federal licensing.
Departments are reorganizing to reduce administrative costs. They are automating and finding innovative new ways to respond to the needs of Canadians. Improved management of Canada's cash inflows and outflows has saved taxpayers billions of dollars over the last six years, while assets are managed more efficiently.

In this regard this House last year passed legislative changes to the Financial Administration Act and the federal Real Property Act. What most taxpayers do not realize is that if Canadians did not have to pay interest on the national debt, the federal government would actually be running a $12.6 billion surplus in the last fiscal year, that is 1990-91, rather than a deficit. This represents a $28.5 billion turnaround since 1984-85. It is so important that people realize that we have made substantial progress in reducing the cost of government.
I do not think anyone can doubt that this sort of performance improvement represents a spectacular achievement in business terms. Yet it is almost completely unknown and unheralded. By and large taxpayers and clients of the federal programs do not know this. I think members of this House, myself included, must accept some responsibility for this situation.
The passage of Bill C-26 now before us would permit the performance and improvement process to continue. It would add new dimensions to the reform process and invigorate it, complementing other ongoing planned performance improvement. It would reaffirm the merit principle of Public Service staffing and respond to employee concerns about their careers, as well as manage concerns about lack of flexibility to serve the public better through deployment of staff.
To address the issue of career movement which has affected employee morale and hence service at the counter, narrow job classifications would be combined and simplified to provide for broader job groupings allowing easier mobility for professional development purposes.
With more career movement, employees would be able to acquire new skills and work experience through increased lateral movement where promotions are not possible. Yet they would still have access to a system of redress to ensure that delegated authorities are not abused.
Provisions for demotion and release would be consolidated and transferred to the Financial Administration Act. Service to the public would be further improved with proposed changes to make it easier to hire casual staff for short periods, unexpected workloads and seasonal work.
Government Orders
Most hon. members would agree that changes must be made in the area of Public Service labour relations. With the passage of Bill C-26, relations between the employer and its unions would be improved through the introduction of more flexibility and the elimination of confining bureaucratic rules and procedures.
I want to stress that there has been a lot of consultation with government unions in this area. Bill C-26 proposes measures to address difficulties that result from trying to conduct employer-union relations in the 1990s under 25-year old legislation. Bill C-26 would open up new options for both parties and speed up the process of dispute resolution.
All members are aware that Canada is an increasingly diverse society. Canada needs a Public Service that better reflects the society it serves, one where all Canadians, including those who are members of ethnic and visible minorities and other employment equity groups, have equal access to employment and career opportunities.
With the passage of Bill C-26, the Treasury Board Secretariat and the Public Service Commission, two key central agencies, would be able to work more closely to ensure that special programs are established to ease the recruitment and advancement of members of employment equity groups. These reforms would improve the chances of these Canadians finding satisfying careers and help make the department and agencies of government more reflective of the public being served.
Bill C-26 would help enshrine values in the Public Service that are Canada's values, including those of fairness and of equity of opportunity. The federal Public Service is a vital national institution that warrants refurbishing and revitalizing to better serve Canadians.
The former Auditor General, Kenneth Dye, stood firmly behind Public Service 2000, as does the current Auditor General, Denis Desautels. Auditor General Dye said in his 1990 report that "fundamental change is needed in the way we manage people. Since my last report", Mr. Dye said, "the public accounts committee has devoted six hearings to the subject of management of people in the Public Service. At those hearings it became evident that notwithstanding some concerns about the process of Public Service 2000, there was a strong consensus shared by committee and witnesses that the

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
legislative and administrative reforms are urgently needed".
The treasury board president said, when he introduced this bill, that "Canadians expect a Public Service that is effective and up to date, one staffed and led by Canada's ablest men and women, which is to say a Public Service that, though 125 years old this year, is thoroughly modem in its approach to serving Canadians".
Businesses everywhere today are competing fiercely and are restructuring. In turn, public services around the world are changing and modernizing their operations and attitudes to better serve their clients in the private sector. This is where the bulk of the jobs are created and the private sector is demanding closer collaboration and co-operation from governments. They are also demanding that governments reduce the cost of providing their services. Canadian businesses deserve to be supported by a lean and efficient federal Public Service, one that is more client centred and service oriented, one that listens to and collaborates more with the job creators of industry, the way they do in Japan, Germany and other industrialized nations.
Therefore, Bill C-26 can help assure that the reform process, Public Service 2000 already under way, continues in the future. I hope that all members of this House will support the passage of this bill.

Mr. Speaker, as Canada moves toward its 125th birthday and as we move with the rest of the world toward the third millennium, we are looking carefully at all our national institutions and how they can better serve Canadians in the years to come.
It is appropriate that the Public Service of Canada, one of the institutions that has allowed this Parliament for one and a quarter centuries to carry out the will of Parliament and to carry out services that are essential to Canadians from coast to coast to coast, that that institution also be re-examined.
The purpose of PS 2000 should be, and the purpose of our review of this bill should be, to ensure that the Public Service of Canada is ready to move into the next century and is ready to adapt to change both at home and around the world in providing both policy advice to government, the enforcement of government laws and regulations and direct services to Canadians.
The Liberal Party believes Canadians deserve quality services accessible to all Canadians and delivered by a competent, efficient, professional and non-partisan Public Service, a Public Service that treats all employees with respect and fairness, and is responsive to the needs of all Canadians without favouritism and without fear. The Liberal Party believes that the development of this nation has been a partnership, a partnership between the public and private sector, including non-governmental organizations, business, labour, people at all levels of society, and that that kind of partnership is going to become even more important as we move into a rapidly changing future.
We also believe that the public and private partnership has been well served by a Public Service working in partnership with government to provide policy advice to government, to provide services to Canadians. Nothing that has been decided in this Chamber since Confederation makes one bit of difference without a good competent Public Service out there carrying out the will of Parliament and bringing back to us the concerns of Canadians and an analysis of change that is needed.
The Liberal Party agrees that revitalization of the Public Service to meet the changing circumstances of the future is absolutely essential. We agree that there is a need to adapt to changes which will become increasingly frequent, increasingly unpredictable and increasingly severe, leading us in new directions that we cannot even predict today.
What we need in our Public Service, as we need throughout society, is creative, innovative people, adaptable to the changing needs of their clients and the nation. We need the ability to attract and retain competent, dedicated employees, as the hon. member opposite has said. The best this country has to offer should be in the Public Service at the service of their fellow citizens.
We need to have the kind of Public Service where those people will feel challenged, satisfied, and as they have for 125 years, feel not only that they have a job, but that they are making a contribution to their country.
We believe as Liberals that change can best be managed in the climate of respect, trust, co-operation and consultation with employees and with clients of the Government of Canada. We also believe that accountability to Parliament and to the public for the management of their human and financial resources is an
February 10,1992

essential ingredient of good government and good Public Service.
As Liberals we also recognize that the Public Service has been essential to the building of a nation. This is a country that was created, not out of natural ties of economy or geography or long history, but of people from different backgrounds living in different regions with different natural surroundings and resources to depend on, deciding and developing the political will to create a country.
That needs the leadership of Parliament, but it also needs a dedicated Public Service prepared to buy into that dream and in their daily working lives to make that dream happen.
Public policy led us, long in advance of need, to build a railway across this country. It led us to establish a postal service to the remote regions of Canada over time. It led us to establish a national broadcasting corporation so that every Canadian, no matter how far from the centres of political and economic power could feel part of this country. It led us to establish a national airlines so that all parts of Canada could benefit equally from progress in technology and transportation. In time it led us into space so that Canada could continue to be a part of telecommunications technology that would be important to us for our future as well. It was the Public Service of Canada that took essential services to the frontiers, truly made it possible for every Canadian to share in what we had decided as a country were certain rights of citizenship, to service, to communication, to travel, to belonging to Canada.
Not only were these essential communication and transportation links a matter of public policy, they were a matter of public policy implemented by a Public Service. What we see is the importance of retaining the Public Service as a strong federal institution, capable of fulfilling that role into the future. Yes, changing, yes, developing, but not being so weakened that the will of this Parliament cannot be carried out.
The whole public role in the development of this country has been part of respecting differences, equalizing disparity of opportunity across Canada, accommodating differences whether they are of geography, of opportunity, wherever people are in Canada. This Ixisto-

ry we share has made this country the envy of the world and we see a lot now of the forces of divisiveness trying to rip that apart. So as we talk about the Public Service today, it is more than a question of how does a bureaucracy function; it is a question of how does a country function. How do we tie this nation together? How do we continue to have a strong public role in the building of Canada in the future?
We have to deal with change and it is more important than ever that we know who we are and where we are going. That is something not defined only in the marketplace; that is something defined in the minds and hearts of people and reflected in this Chamber and then taken back out to the nation through those we appoint and direct to deliver the services of government to Canadians. It is also a circle of communication and allowing that Public Service to feed back to us as parliamentarians the new and emerging needs of Canadians and how we can meet them better.
We do not want to go into the future with this new global competitiveness homogenizing Canada out of existence. Retaining our identity and retaining our independence and retaining our ability to be a different voice in the world, for diversity, for mutual respect, for human rights, retaining that leadership role for Canada depends on retaining the ability of government to make public policy that is distinctively Canadian and have it carried out by a Public Service that is distinctively Canadian.
As I look at this bill, I can only conclude the ways of the Tory government are the ways of the past, not the ways of the future. The government has shown in numerous ways that it cannot manage change and it is demonstrating it again today. We have only to look at things like the free trade agreement that have inhibited the ability of Canadians to manage things our own way, to make our own decisions, to look after the best interests of Canadians first.
We have only to look back through the years from 1984 when we had a strong, vibrant economy that put us in a position to be able to get people prepared for change, to pay down our deficit, to pay down our debt, to work on new training programs, to work on adjustment to change. Instead, we have a debt that has continued to rise, a deficit that has continued to rise, high interest rates, higher taxes, a high dollar, all of which have impeded

Canada adapting to the changing environment in the world.
We see instead of helping people adapt to change a government that is abandoning those most in need as economic change and upheaval takes place. We see it, for instance, in the cap on CAP transfers to provinces, so that those who are hurting most because of the economic mismanagement of the country are not able to access training, are not able to access what they need to help them through a difficult time.
We see what I believe is an old Tory philosophy at work, that those with money and power somehow know better what is good for us and if we only leave everything in their hands they will look after the rest of us. That does not seem to work out. In fact it seems to work out just the opposite.
It has been said that government is there to moderate the voracious appetites and directions of the private market. Again, we are talking about public policy and the delivery of public services.
The government has shown clearly that it cannot even manage its own employees. We have had the first ever full-scale walkout of public service employees in the history of Canada. We have had downsizing, contracting out, privatization, at which even the Auditor General and the public accounts committee have thrown up their hands in horror because of the complete lack of accountability as to the cost effectiveness of those measures.
In addition to its problems managing, this government seems to have trouble keeping trust with Canadians. We see a pretence at restraint so we cannot give people earning $18,000 a year an increase, but we can give increases to people earning high salaries, up to a quarter or one-third of a million dollars. Just this summer we saw judges earning up to $175,000 getting full cost of a spokesperson for the Treasury Board saying: "Oh, well, the wage restraint on members of Parliament was just a smoke screen to give credibility to our wage freeze".
Either we are in a period of restraint and everybody is in restraint, or we are simply seeing an attempt to take those at the lowest end of the scale and push them down
even lower. That is certainly the impression Canadians got of this government this summer.
We have seen the betrayal of the trust of Canadians with the GST. At a time when inflation was a problem this government chose to bring in an inflationary new tax that is hardest on those who can least afford it. We have seen the betrayal of the trust of seniors concerning their pensions. We have seen the betrayal of the trust of farmers who have been told for months: "Don't worry about it. We are looking after it. We will protect supply management". Now we know that is not what was going on behind closed doors. We have seen the betrayal of the needy in tough economic times.
This government promised consultation with its employees on reform. The President of the Treasury Board said that no legislation would come through except that on which there was agreement by all parties. Yet we have a bill here that is roundly condemned by representatives of the employees and an insistence by the government on blindly pushing ahead with its own agenda regardless of who gets hurt, regardless of all the good advice it has had that this is not the way to go.
We heard the member speak about service to the public as the purpose of PS 2000. Can we trust that when the very last report of PS 2000 that was written was a service to the public report? It should have been the first report. It should have been the foundation of all the recommendations that have come before it.
We have seen the government ignoring court decisions that say you cannot simply let managers move people around. That is an abandonment of the whole merit principle. The court said that less than two weeks ago. Yet we have the government bringing in a bill that does exactly that and expands the ability of managers to do exactly that.
We have seen the government attempting to thwart moves toward equity for women in the Public Service by fighting in court the right of those employees to have their cases heard by the Human Rights Commission.
The purpose of this government since 1984-and it is a purpose that has been perpetuated by this bill-has been the dismantling and the weakening of a Public Service
February 10, 1992

that has been important to our history and has linked Canadians from coast to coast, just as VIA Rail, air service, our national airlines and postal services have been ripped out of small town Canada. The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation is no longer able to serve and reflect the two official language groups as it once did, to reflect the regions to each other and to themselves. Just as these services that have linked us as Canadians are disappearing under this government, so too is our Public Service.
I want to speak about three particular things that are affected by this bill. Since 1919 it has been the proud claim of Canadians that we have a Public Service where you get a job because you are the best qualified person for that job. This is the merit principle.
The Civil Service Commission was established in 1919 specifically to get rid of rampant patronage and favouritism in the Public Service at both the political and the administrative levels. We have been through periods in our history when if the member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell were elected in the next election he could walk into any government office in his riding and say: "You're fired. I am bringing in my guys who are loyal to me to deliver services to the public". We got rid of that kind of Public Service decades ago.
Yet here we have again an abandonment of the merit principle, a bill that now says being the best qualified does not count any more. Your boss, your foreman, your manager, your deputy minister will be able to decide on his or her own if you are good enough to get moved around where the opportunities are to advance and to improve your skills. No review and no recourse, totally arbitrary decisions by individuals within the Public Service, and no protection.
I recommend to members that before they deal with this bill they read the decision of the Federal Court of Canada just two weeks ago that said: "This kind of activity is contrary to the merit principle". Yet we have a government that says: "Yes, we want to introduce provisions and we want to expand provisions that are contrary to the merit principle". It acted illegally and beyond its powers two years ago when it said: "Move people around wherever you want to". Now it wants to change the law so that it can do just that at will.
It is not much wonder people in the Public Service are concerned about harassment and intimidation when whether your manager likes you or does not like you

becomes the criteria by which you will either get opportunities or not get opportunities. No wonder women, visible minorities and persons with disabilities feel that the old image of who can do the job best is going to prevail even more than it has in the past.
To get rid of the merit principle is a step back in time. It is a step back to when the Public Service was the place to reward your friends and punish your enemies. We only have to look around the world to know that developing countries, those countries where human rights and political rights are most at risk, are those countries where the military is more important than the Public Service. One sign of a developing country that is beginning to make progress is an efficient, impartial public service, and yet this government wants to destroy that in Canada.
Liberals believe in equal opportunities for everybody in employment and progress within the Public Service. We believe that there should be a very strong provision in this bill that requires the government to implement employment equity. This is the largest employer in the country. It should also be the leading employer when it comes to giving every person, regardless of gender, regardless of colour, regardless of what disabilities they may have, equal opportunity to use the abilities they do have in the service of their fellow citizens.
Yet we have a provision in this bill that is so wishy-washy the government should be embarrassed to call it an employment equity clause. It says that if Treasury Board feels like it, it may tell the Public Service Commission that the Public Service Commission may implement employment equity programs.
I think the government should start listening to the Canadian Chamber of Commerce when it says that if the private sector is to be subject to employment equity legislation, the least the government can do is make itself subject to employment equity legislation. This bill is the place to do it.
We have had documentation for decades of the ways in which certain groups are not deemed to be competent. Beneath the Veneer, the report of task force on Barriers to Women in the Public Service, demonstrated again, if we needed to have it demonstrated, that what prevented women from advancing in the Public Service of Canada, the reason they were nearly half the Public Service but

February 10,1992
Government Orders
less than 15 per cent of management, for instance, was attitudes, attitudes that I do not blame anybody for. They are so ingrained in us that we have certain images of who is competent and who can succeed.
We have to discard those attitudes. In a society that is diverse, if we want a Public Service that reflects that diversity, we have to discard those attitudes. We are not going to discard those attitudes if, as this bill does, we reinforce the right to make arbitrary choices on the part of managers and of deputy ministers. That would be a move back in time, and that is not what this country needs.
I want to speak briefly about the process of PS 2000. When the current Public Service Employment Act and the current Public Service Staff Relations Act were brought in 25 years ago, it was the result of a long process of consultation. It was not done in isolation. It was done publicly. It was done inviting submissions not only from top managers but from employees, from labour unions, from academics, from the public who were the clients of the Public Service.
Yet here we are all these years later saying that managers can do this. They do not have to negotiate and collaborate with their employees. They do not have to bring their clients into this process to determine how to improve the Public Service. Again the government is showing it cannot consult with its own employees. How can we take seriously the recommendation of its task force report on service to the public to consult with the public on services to it?
This is a one-sided bill by the government for the government, not for the public, not for its employees, and not for the future of Canada. It is another step back to the past that reinforces hierarchy and that reinforces top down paternalism. We believe there are ways of giving managers more freedom without trampling on the rights of other people.
The theme song of PS 2000 has been: Let the Managers Manage. That theme song comes from the 1962 Glassco commission. It is 30 years later; we are now in 1992. We are ready for the future, not the past.
We hear a lot about managing change, but leadership is not dictatorship. Leadership is not trampling on other people's rights to free up the arbitrary discretion of some people. We know that morale in the Public Service is at
an all-time low. People have seen their work being contracted out, privatized, downsized, and yet the public accounts committee has taken the government to task for not being able to account for whether that is improving the situation, improving cost effectiveness or not.
We have had the Auditor General chastising the government because it does not know what it is doing with its money. It cannot begin to say what it is spending on contracting, and what privatization has produced in benefits, if anything. It cannot possibly go out to the public and say that this is all saving money. It simply does not know. That is irresponsible.
Yet it has gone out to the public and said that cutting the Public Service, keeping it at zero increase and trampling it into the ground is the way to cut the deficit. It has not told the public that less than 12 per cent of federal spending applies to the Public Service. It has tried to divert the attention from the other 88 per cent of its spending to the quarter million people who simply want to do a good job for their fellow citizens.
There are a number of provisions in this bill to which other colleagues of mine will speak. The government is abandoning the merit principle by allowing managers to move people around at will with no recourse. It is changing the classifications so that employment equity and pay equity become even more difficult to achieve. This new deployment then becomes a means of promoting and demoting without review or any consideration of merit principle. It is getting rid of competitions and saying that any qualified person will do. It does not have to be the best qualified any more. Pick up the phone, call your nephew and tell him you have a job which he is qualified for. Tell him to come on in and get on the payroll. There will be the free ability to contract out, when the government cannot even now account for its contracting out and when the courts have said it is not legal for the government to contract out and lay off employees. To go ahead with this piece of legislation is simply not right.
There are some good things in the bill, and of course we will be looking to improve it. The public accounts committee, after weeks of very careful hearings and excellent research, made a recommendation to the House of Commons and to the government that this
February 10, 1992

legislation should not be considered in isolation, that is only 10 per cent of the PS 2000 process and before legislation comes in, the whole process of PS 2000 should be referred to a special committee of the House. It should all be reviewed. The comments of all affected stakeholders, a phrase the government is fond of using, should be invited. Parliament itself should carry out the third party, impartial monitoring and recommendations, as opposed to managers simply proposing what is suitable to them.
Bill C-26 may pass but reform in the Public Service will fail. The private sector is finding out we cannot have reform or change without everyone being on side and on board. Yet the government has deliberately excluded the employees and the public from this process.
We believe the public accounts committee was right when it said that legislation should not be adopted before a special committee of Parliament had an opportunity to hold full consultations. We do not believe the valuable work of PS 2000 should be wasted. It is one step, and it is the first step in a bigger process. The managers and the government are not the only ones whose views need to be considered.
I wish to move a motion that would in fact implement the recommendations of the public accounts committee. We considered suggesting referring this bill to the consumer and corporate affairs and government operations committee, but we recognized that committee is overloaded. This job needs to be done quickly and efficiently by a group of parliamentarians who are focusing on this, and not on credit card rates and all the other things consumer and corporate affairs and government operations committee deals with.
We once again want to urge the government to consider establishing a special committee. For that reason we believe this bill should not be debated at second reading now but should be sent to a committee for pre-study. We have made that clear to the government, and so I move the following motion: [DOT]
That this motion be amended by deleting all of the words after the word "that" and by substituting the following therefor:
Government Orders
Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada, be not now read a second time but be read a second time this day six months hence.
Hopefully that will give the House leaders time to consult on the establishment of a special committee so that we can have a report on the legislation back before this House very expeditiously that will truly prepare the Public Service for the next century and give us a reform package that is worthy of the aspirations of Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, I too wish to rise and speak on Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada.
It is very evident this government is changing the laws of Canada so it is no longer subject to any impartial review. Over the last many decades we have developed a system of using the Public Service Staff Relations Board and the Public Service Commission to make sure the government does not arbitrarily change the rules of the game to suit itself.
Just recently the Federal Court has ruled that the actions of the federal government in relation to its employees and its transfer policies go against the legislation that is in place.
This legislation is not good, management driven, but management driven in such a way that managers are no longer subject to any impartial review. In other words, transfers, deployments and appointments can take place, but the affected employees are not really in a position to seek an independent decision as to whether or not the government has made its decision, or senior management has made its decision, on the basis of good judgment.

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
We are all concerned with some of the bureaucracy that exists in this country. We are all concerned with making a lot of issues, including employment and promotion, a lot simpler. We are all concerned with making sure that the government gets the best bang for the buck. Those are common concerns. But that is not what this legislation is doing. Government spokespersons who get up and say they are making it simpler and allowing managers to manage are not looking at the clauses in this legislation.
As I said earlier, there would almost be unanimous agreement in this House that there are ways for the government to manage better. There are ways of allowing managers to make decisions, but it is completely unnecessary to go to the limits that are in this legislation.
This legislation is basically gutting the Public Service Commission of Canada. It is ignoring the Public Service Employment Act. It is gutting the role of the Public Service Staff Relations Board. These three important groups have tried to make sure that we have a Public Service based on merit and not favouritism or political appointment.
I find it ironic that the federal government is spending $5 billion a year on contracting out, without investigating whether it is cost effective or not. This government is doing this and says that contracting out will not be subject to any review. If you lose your job as a result of contracting out, that is too bad. It is too bad.
We now have a minister in the House which is a welcome change. We should get legislation that is fair to all people. If there is a problem with a process that is too cumbersome then change that process but do not take away all rights of the employees. Do not say you cannot apply for a lateral promotion. It was very evident from a court case which the federal government just lost that a lateral appointment or transfer can be a promotion for some people because you gain experience. You gain a variety of training that you would not gain if you remained in the same job.
That is exactly what the Federal Court ruled when it said this government was in violation of its own laws. The government is saying that if you are transferred from one position to another it is really none of your business. That is not true. The government is saying it does not
matter if you have a lateral transfer because you are doing the same job or getting the same salary and it does not affect your future. That is also not true. The Federal Court of Appeal has said it is obvious that if a person wants to apply for a job in a different area within the same category, he will be gaining valuable experience and knowledge that will make it easier to move up the corporate ladder within the department.
I believe that the way this legislation has been proposed by this government means we will not have high morale in the Public Service. We will not have an impartial Public Service. We will have decisions made by deputy department heads which have absolutely nothing to do with an impartial system. The whole basis of this legislation is that it will be up to the department heads to create a new structure. It will be up to the department heads to decide who does what, what classification they are in, and who will be eligible to apply for a job. If you do not like the fact that you are not eligible for a job or that you are put in a new classification, to whom do you appeal? You appeal to the very person who made that decision. What kind of justice is that?
I do not believe that even this Conservative government would introduce this type of legislation for the people who work under the Canada Labour Code. It will do it for the very people who work for the Government of Canada. In other words, when you work for the Government of Canada and the people of Canada, you do not have the same rights you would have if you were working in private industry.
What irony that is. Do you know who the decision makers will be in this process? They will be the senior people at the very top, people whose decisions will not be subject to any real review. Not only that, the people who wall make the general guidelines and rules will be the employees at the management level of Treasury Board.
Treasury Board not only is going to be making decisions that affect classification, affect your right to seek a transfer, affect deployment within the Public Service, they are also going to be determining classification. They are going to make all these decisions. They are going to determine who can bargain with whom, what collective agreements will be in place.
