To make sure that Treasury Board is not going to find itself in a situation where their decisions are subject to review or where their workers might say things are unfair, the federal government under this legislation is saying that anybody who works for Treasury Board does not really have any rights whatsoever. It does nothing to make sure that if the government decides to contract out-and it is doing so at the rate of $5 billion a year already-that this will be subject to any

This was a committee with members from all parties and as I said, with a Conservative majority saying that if decisions are made to contract out that there should be a study. There should be some understanding as to whether or not that is cost-effective. That was a very reasonable recommendation.

In addition, and I think we have seen it before, the ability to contract out without any review only increases the amount of political patronage that will exist.
We have lobbyists, some who are registered and some who are not registered, lining up around this building applying for contracts, working for their friends. We do not know how much that is costing the taxpayers of Canada, but we do know that it could be a tremendous amount.
We know of Conservatives who get appointed when there are Conservatives in power. We know of Liberals who are appointed when there are Liberals in power. That happens already and it happens too much. There is an old joke, the only people who get rich in Canada are the consultants and the lawyers.

What we are doing is institutionalizing a system where, department by department, decisions will not be made on the basis of merit and where contracting out will not be done on the basis of what is cost effective.

What will be done is that when these decisions are made, the public will not know what the decisions are and the people who are affected will lose any real right to appeal to some form of impartial arbitrator.
We know that the federal government has lost any number of cases on employment equity. It has lost cases with regard to the arbitrary transfer system.
Why has the government lost these cases before the Federal Court? The reason is that the federal government was not following any form of reasonable practice. They were making arbitrary decisions that the Federal Court of this land said were unacceptable.
Not one, not two, but number after number after number of cases have come down saying the federal government does not obey its own laws, that it is arbitrary. It does not follow the very nature of the law; that it is unjust by its application of that law.
So what is the government's remedy? To become fair? To become less arbitrary? To follow due process? No. What it is doing with Bill C-26 is saying: "We are not going to worry about fairness any more. We are not going to worry about due process any more. We are not going to worry about being cost effective any more. We will just change the law and say that we do not do that any more. Mr. Speaker, you will recall that one of the key recommendations contained in Public Service 2000, the renewal of the Public Service of Canada, was to provide more flexibility for the deployment of employees to meet both operational and career development needs.
By deployment we mean the transfer of any employee from one position to another where there is no promotion occurring and where the tenure or employment status of the employee does not change.
It is important to consider the subject of deployment in the context that was described in the Public Service 2000 white paper. As you will recall, the central theme of Public Service 2000 is improved service to Canada and Canadians. It has recognized that the key to improved service is public servants themselves.
Public Service managers need to be able to manage their staffs in such a way as to provide a continuing and increasingly high quality of service to the public. They need to be able to move their employees quickly to where they are needed and to be able to develop their employees to meet new and changing priorities.
Employees need to be given the opportunity to achieve their career aspirations and to use their skills, their ideas, and their enthusiasm in the public interest. Indeed, as most organizations both public and private are discovering, there is a need to develop a continuous learning culture, to ensure that organizations and employees adapt to a rapidly changing world.
With the deployment provisions in Bill C-26 the government has found a way to balance the interests of Public Service managers to get the work done quickly and well and the interests of employees to be treated fairly and to have opportunities to learn and to develop satisfying careers.
Let me take a few moments to describe the deployment provisions that are being introduced and to tell you why we believe these changes will be effective.
Under the current Public Service Employment Act all appointments to and within the Public Service are subject to the merit principle. What this has meant in practice is that before a manager could transfer or deploy an employee, even for temporary periods, the manager would have to compare employees by competi-
February 10, 1992

tion or otherwise, and choose the best qualified among them.
The manager's decision was then subject to challenge from those who were not successful or felt that they should have the opportunity to be considered.
I would remind you, Mr. Speaker, that virtually every step in the staffing process is legislated or regulated and this has resulted in a staffing system often driven by the need to pass potential scrutiny. The result is a staffing system that is slow, cumbersome and complex.
This complex system has hindered the efforts of managers to improve efficiency, to move employees quickly to where they are needed, to fulfil developmental needs and to deal with situations that require compassion such as an employee who must move to be near medical facilities.
When persons are recruited to or promoted within the Public Service they must prove themselves in ways determined by the Public Service Commission to be not only qualified but indeed the best qualified persons for the job.
The Public Service Commission will continue to be responsible for recruitment and promotion on the basis of merit.
Once employees have proven themselves capable of performing duties at a given level of responsibility it should not be necessary to do a complete reassessment of their capabilities and more particularly, to compare them to all other potential candidates.
I do want to emphasize that although it will not be required in law to select the best qualified employee for a deployment, it will be necessary to ensure that employees being deployed are indeed qualified and in particular that they meet the standards for such matters as security, medical requirements, and language.
Treasury Board policy will reinforce this point.
You will also recall, Mr. Speaker, that one of the underlying principles of Public Service 2000 was the need to trust and empower managers and to allow them to use their judgment in the interests of service to the public.
Government Orders
Our managers are competent, trained and committed. They are indeed capable of making decisions about their employees and how their employees can be best managed and they need the freedom to do so. Furthermore, they need the freedom to discuss and to decide with their employees the best way of meeting their employees' career aspirations and developmental needs.
The deployment provisions recognize this. Deployment will be the exclusive authority of department deputy heads subject to direction from the Treasury Board.
The Treasury Board does not intend to tie the hands of deputy heads but rather intends to ensure that there is some consistency of approach throughout the Public Service and that Public Service wide interests are taken into account.
In developing the deployment proposals, the government was cognizant of the concerns being expressed particularly from some of the Public Service unions. Two very important protections for employees have been included in these proposals.
First, deployments must be made with the consent of the employee concerned, except in those relatively rare cases in which a willingness to be deployed is a condition of employment. A good example of this would be the foreign service, in which the nature of the work requires employees to move to different locations periodically. In such cases, employees will know before they accept a particular job that this condition applies and that they can accept or reject the job with full knowledge of this.
The second protection is the recourse process that has been designed for deployment. Employees being deployed, or those in the work unit to which their deployment is occurring, will have the opportunity to challenge the deployment on the grounds that it was not authorized by or made in accordance with the statute or that it constituted an abuse of authority.
An employee will first make a complaint to the deputy head who will investigate and take such action as is appropriate. If the employee is still unhappy with the proposed resolution, he or she may go to the Public Service Commission, which will appoint an investigator to look into the situation and recommend a course of action to the deputy head.

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
If the investigator is not satisfied with the response of the deputy head, the investigator shall report the matter to the Public Service Commission, which will have the authority to order corrective action.
There is one final point I would like to make. The proposals in Bill C-26 will not require managers to consider for deployment persons whose names appear on priority lists before proceeding with the deployment of another employee.
This is a change from the current situation in which priority persons would be considered before others. I know that some members will be concerned about this, and I want to explain the rationale behind this decision.
Over the years departments have done a very good job of reintegrating employees who face lay-offs or otherwise have priority for a reappointment. Deputy heads have displayed a very strong commitment to their employees to the point of often creating their own internal no lay-off policies.
Furthermore, departments must abide with the provisions of the work force adjustment policy, which was recently agreed to with the Public Service unions. Given this, it was felt that it was not necessary to constrain further the flexibility that managers are being given with new deployment provisions. However, I do want to assure members that the Treasury Board is prepared to impose the consideration of priority persons on its own initiative or at the request of a deputy head if future circumstances warrant it.
In closing, I would reiterate that the proposed process allows for the simplification of employee movement but not at the expense of employee input and recourse. It provides a mechanism for managers and employees to create a continuous learning environment.
It provides deputy heads with the legislative framework to meet the particular needs of their organizations, provide service to the public and develop employees.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to address this portion of the debate on Bill C-26.
As I open my remarks I want to focus on what I believe to be some of the important Liberal Party perspectives on this very important Public Service reorganization bill.
I think it is fair to say that while we may have some agreement around the House on some of the principles, there are elements of this bill with which our party has significant difficulty.
I would like to go over some of the principles with which I am hopeful all members in the House will be in general agreement. As we approach this bill and what will undoubtedly be a material and substantial reorganization of the way the government deals with its Public Service and the way it provides services to Canadians, the first principle is that we believe Canadians deserve accessible and quality services delivered efficiently by a professional, non-partisan Public Service that treats all employees with respect and fairness, and one that is responsive to the needs of Canadians who pay the bills.
I am sure there will not be many in the House who would disagree with that.
The second principle I would like to put on the record is one in which my party and I believe. It is that we support the revitalization of the Public Service to better allow the Public Service to adapt to rapid change and to create an environment in which the employees of the Public Service can be creative, innovative and adaptable to the changing needs of their clients-all Canadians and the country-and to attract and retain competent, dedicated employees.
Last, the Liberal Party and I are committed to the principle of accountability to Parliament and to the public for the use of both human and financial resources.
There are other principles and subdivisions which we could debate further today, but I want to leave the list at that and affirm my support for those principles.
Over the last little while, since I have become a member of this House, I have had an opportunity to see the workings of some public services of some other countries and some other jurisdictions such as provinces, constituencies, states, et cetera. At almost every juncture, I come away impressed with the level of service, the efficacy and the professionalism of the Canadian Public Service. That did not happen by luck. It happened, I suppose, by design and by the good efforts of those who are in Public Service and by members of government
February 10, 1992

who assisted in the development of the Public Service over the last number of decades.
There was a significant departure made in the year 1919, when the country committed itself to a professional, non-partisan Public Service. Since then, right up to the present, we have been building. It is not like we have not had our difficulties between then and now. There has been an increase in the organization of the Public Service through collective agreements, and the work of government has become more intrusive and more complex. Consequently the Public Service has become more sophisticated and more dedicated to those services, or those intrusions from the perspectives of some people.
In any event, the work of government has become more complex and is more demanding of the Public Service. Therefore, the Public Service must keep pace. It is likely that some of the structures within our Public Service, as they have evolved over these decades, are not suited to the demands of modem government.
Being impressed with the current state of affairs within the Canadian Public Service is not enough, because we know, the Public Service knows and government knows that there are some improvements and changes needed.
Bill C-26 contains many different legislative proposals with respect to the Public Service.
I am concerned with the apparent provisions that would devolve or permit the devolution of certain types of authority out of the rules and structures as exist now in the Pubic Service, a devolution of those authorities and decision making into the hands of managers and into the hands of individuals as opposed to the structured institution.
Over time this institution of the Public Service has not done too badly. The structures that are there serve Canadians reasonably well. Certainly they do not serve perfectly at this point, but they have served the country well.
What I am concerned about now is that as we devolve these authorities from rules, regulations and structures to the hands of managers, will the overriding principle of advancement based on merit continue along and be as important to the Public Service as it has been in the past? I think it is fair to say that the merit principle is
Government Orders
important to Canadians. I think Canadians would want to know that Public Service advancement and hiring were done on the basis of merit.
There is a concern among people in the Public Service and among people who work with the Public Service that this authority, devolved into the hand of a particular person, may be efficient at some point and may be very effective but over all if we look behind the principle, if we look behind what is happening here, there is a diminishing, an abandoning of the singular importance of the merit principle in hiring and advancement.
I am concerned about that. Everyone in the Public Service starts off as a basic human being. We are all prone-at the top of the list are politicians-to forming opinions and judgments and doing things based on what we individually feel is best. If we walk away from the merit principle as the chief criterion for advancement in hiring, will we then have to confront at the manager level, not at the structural level up top, potential problems based on a bunch of isms such as nepotism, racism, sexism, and all of these ways of looking at life that human beings adopt? If we are going to abandon the merit principle, will that open the door to decisions made less professionally and by individuals who believe they are right, but whose decisions of hiring and advancement are based on isms which we do not want to make a part of our Public Service hiring and promotion criteria?
I leave that on a cautionary note. I want to state very firmly that I would not support an abandonment of the merit principle as the basis on which hiring and promotions are made in the Public Service.
I want to move to a related area: the business of promotion, demotion and hiring. In the current Public Service Employment Act, sections 21 and 31 provide for a system of appeal by public servants. There is a right to appeal when there is a decision made to terminate you as a result of incompetence or incapacity or when a decision is made to give an appointment to someone without a competition. I know that the matter has come before the House before, and I refer to the ninth report of the Standing Joint Committee for the Scrutiny of Regulations. It basically stated that the policy and procedures of these grievance appeals, these very important mechanisms whereby the Public Service can appeal these extremely important decisions critical to individual careers, were not fair. That is actually a fairly stinging

February 10,1992
Government Orders
indictment of the process. If the procedure is not fair then it should not be there. It should be changed.
This issue has been before Parliament for many years and the changes have not been made. That is why I am raising it now in this debate because presumably these procedures will be contained in regulations under the new bill, and the issue will be discussed in the bill. Provisions enabling the regulations will have to be a part of the bill. I want to make very sure this House knows that this particular committee of the House has reported without an appropriate response. The committee representing all three parties of this House was unanimous in its report.
The government and the Public Service have not responded favourably. They basically responded with a big zero. That means they are not listening, or they are listening and they are stubborn, or they are listening and they do not care. Whatever it is, it means that government is not working.
I would like to review the three problem areas that I believe should be addressed in this particular bill. The first is the issue of disclosure of relevant information to an appellant before the appeal takes place. The Public Service Commission replied to us in this House that it believed its policy and procedures were just fine. Yet this Parliament, through its committee, has evidence that sometimes the relevant information is disclosed to the appellant and sometimes it is not.
I am trying to paraphrase: "Really it did not create much unfairness. I think everything works just fine, thank you very much". But that is a sham. If there is not disclosure before a hearing, how can the appellant hope to deal with the information that is being put before the hearing? I submit that the appellant cannot.
This principle of fair disclosure exists across the whole breadth and scope of legal and judicial procedures in this country. I cannot imagine that it does not exist in every single court in every single corner of this country. Yet in our very own Public Service procedures for appeal it does not exist. The Public Service and the evidence we
have acknowledge that sometimes the information is given and sometimes it is not. That is not good enough.
I should point out that the submission by the Public Service Commission that the policy was there and should suffice is really not a very satisfactory response. A policy position that might be printed on a piece of paper or in a memo is not enforceable by an individual appellant. It is not something that the appellant can argue in this procedure. If the fair procedure was in a regulation, it would be something the Public Service must comply with and part of the law of the land. I would argue that anything less than a fair procedure that is installed, printed and published in a regulation is not useful to Canadians in the Public Service.
The second area has to do with the disclosure of Public Service Commission opinions that are relevant to the decision being made about the public servant whose case is being appealed. The Public Service takes the view that its opinions are not to be provided to the appellant, unless the Public Service decides the opinion is useful, but again that is the Public Service. We are talking here about department heads, the higher echelons of management, making decisions and taking positions that have been made known to everyone who was part of the decision-making process in the Public Service but not to the appellant. That is unfair. I do not have to spend much time on that one. I tried to think of a scenario that might be useful here today to explain how unfair that is, but I think the description I have given should suffice.
The third area is the way the Public Service Commission provides its notices of hearing. Again, in every administrative body across this country there are rules of fair procedure regarding the issuance of notices. If you are going to bring someone into a decision-making tribunal then you must give fair notice. It cannot be given one or two days before, but with sufficient time to enable the person to deal with the issues that will be dealt with at the hearing.
I want to close with some thoughts. I have six or seven recommendations to make to the government. First, I believe the government should provide for full and mandatory disclosure to any unsuccessful candidate or the candidate's representative upon request when there is a decision against an appellant.
February 10, 1992

Second, full and mandatory disclosure should be made to an employee of the grounds on which a recommendation was made that he or she be released.
Third, I would suggest that the regulations provide that a department wanting to withhold or limit access to information must have the matter determined by the appeal board at a pre-hearing conference.
Last, the notice period for appeal hearings should be extended to two weeks from the present three-day minimum requirement.
I leave these with the House and point out that these recommendations have been put to the House by government members, opposition members and members of the New Democratic Party. The House should not disregard them, or take them lightly.

Mr. Speaker, I wanted to participate in this debate because I think there is a growing sense across Canada at every level that for a number of reasons governments cannot continue to deal with their employees in a manner such as outlined in this bill.
One of the cautions I would put in beginning my remarks is that a government that sincerely believes all it has to do is pass a law has some lessons to be learned.
In this day and age it is not the way of the real world. It might have been if all other things were equal: if people were paid large amounts of money, if there were a great many perks attached to it, if it was considered to be a great honour. It may be that this kind of unilateral move on the part of a government in legislative form would be, if not understood, then accepted by those in the employ of the government.
I do not believe that is the case any more. I believe a number of people who work for the Government of Canada are unhappy. For those of us who think we should not expect employees to be happy all of the time, there is more of a lesson to be learned. Morale is at an all-time low. Some would simply say the employees of the Government of Canada should not expect to be happy all the time.
That is not the point of the argument. The point is not if they are happy but if they are effective and feel they are an important part of the process.
Government Orders
Nothing could be more demeaning than to have your traditional rights legislated away. That is precisely what is envisaged by this bill. It is an attitude we saw last year around this time when the government began to sense it would not be easy to negotiate a settlement with its employees. It began very early in those negotiations with the attitude that you either settle it or it would legislate you back to work.
Then it seemed to proceed to various little techniques to ensure that would be a self-fulfilling prophecy. Ministers made statements here and there indicating that negotiations were not going very well. They indicated there was a threat involved and that somehow, if the employees would not negotiate exactly the way they wanted them to, they would legislate them back to work.
Of course, as events transpired, that is exactly what happened. When I visited picket lines during that strike there was a great deal of bewilderment and anger. Betrayal is a better word. People who worked for the Government of Canada felt they had a bond. They believed that somehow they were playing an important role in the day-by-day proceedings of this government of ours and would not be treated in this way by their employer. When they were they felt immense anger and frustration.
Many of them were not industrial trade unionists by nature. They belonged to a union, but not in the sense of the steel workers or auto workers where everybody goes to work in one plant for a regular shift. They begin to bond and get some sense of what a union is about. So their attitudes, the way they go about setting up for a strike has a certain ritual to it. People know what it is all about. They do not have to be told what a picket line is and how you go about having a legal picket.
The people I visited had not done this very often. They were not quite sure what it was all about. They had somehow felt all of that would not be necessary. It turned out in the end that it was. It turns out that process continues. That is precisely what this bill does. It assumes that this government can in fact pass a law and that everybody will just follow along lock-step.
The flaw in the argument is simply this. If the government chooses, as it does in this type of legislation, not to offer a reasonable amount of respect or a reasonable process to the people in its employ, it should not expect to get any respect back. It means that you can never accomplish the goals of the bill to get more

February 10,1992
Government Orders
productivity and more initiatives put together. That is a tough argument. I believe it is a true one.
There is a reason why executives of major corporations are doing things now they never did before. They are walking around the shop floor and talking to people. They are gathering their workers in groups to discuss how things happen in the work place. It is not because they want to do that. That is the new initiative in industry where people are beginning to understand some simple truths. It is important that you listen to people in the work place.
It is important to understand that someone who works on a shop floor may have a better understanding of what the functions are in that particular work place than the chief executive officer who has never been there.
Many of the things which the document PS 2000 talks about are notions of a modern industrial way to organize a work place.
In part, the perversion I see in this bill is that it does something by legislative means which will practically forbid any of those good initiatives from coming about because it is not the kind of thing that can be legislated. It particularly is not the kind of thing that can be legislated on the heels of having ripped away from these people their right to negotiate for themselves.
Let me offer a couple of comparisons I think are useful. No level of government is escaping the hard fact that revenues are not the same now as they were even two or three years ago. All governments are beginning now to look at how they spend their money in particular, as that relates to their employees and how the employees are organized.
Some of them at the municipal level are doing the traditional things which would be done when a government is strapped for funds. They call in their chief executive officers and say: "Write a report which tells us how many people at the lower end we have to lay off this year.".
I am pleased to report there are some municipalities that are not doing that. They understand it is unlikely that the manager of a department is ever going to write a report saying: "I am redundant. The rest of the people who work in here are useful. They provide a useful
service, but to be truthful, I cannot figure out what I do in this department".
In fact what you see most often is that most people who manage the department eventually would like to see that department getting larger and larger and larger. Then they too will be able to call somebody in to write the report.
Some municipalities are actually sitting down with all of their employees and they are taking a look at their whole organization, but it really is very simple.
The trick is that no one person can do this. A consultant cannot be called in to write the report. The department heads cannot be called in to do this. If this is to be successful, it has to be a collective effort. It has to be an effort that has all of the employees in the work place participating in a meaningful way and arriving at these decisions.
I noticed at the city of Ottawa where they are going through their budgetary procedures, it started at the top to announce there were some early retirement programs that would be utilized right off the bat. That is unusual because the first instinct usually is to lay off somebody who sweeps the streets or shovels the snow, or somebody who works in the stenographic pool.
At the province of Ontario-which is struggling as everybody else is in the middle of this recession or depression or whatever it is that we are in-there are attempts being made now to look at how all of the systems are organized to provide services.
The lesson that has been learned there simply is that it is understood if this is not put together by everyone as an equal participant, it cannot work.
If the solution to reducing costs and expenditures- and that is the stated goal of almost everybody in politics these days-if that is the intention, if that is what is trying to be done, that function can only really be accomplished when everyone is a participant in it and at every level of government.
It used to be called fat; it used to be called waste. We can now say that there is a lot of counter-productivity in what governments do, in how they go about things. Well that is true, but if we want to remove that, we will not do so unilaterally.
February 10, 1992

That is what is wrong with this bill. This is a unilateral attempt on the part of the federal government of Canada to simply do it by writing a law and the law provides immense opportunities here for management to exercise discretion, to move people around, to change the way of doing things. The problem is that it will not work. If that were the problem, this would have been tried a long time ago.
The problem is: How do you get your productivity up? How do you get all of the people who work for you to participate? How do you get to use all of the energy and the ideas of all the people who form a part of this larger group who are employed by the country of Canada?
That is a great challenge and it is not an easy one. I for one would not want to pretend that this is a simple exercise. This is a long and difficult process at the best of times. It starts in the wrong way though.
Those who would defend this bill would say: "We have been discussing this for quite some time". But that is really not the point.
It is going to take lots of discussion, without question, but at critical times you are tested and the test is simply this. Do you listen to those people with whom you have been discussing these matters? Do you incorporate them into the decision-making process, or at the end of it, when you get a little cranky, do you simply sit down and write a law? That is where this process has broken down.
The Government of Canada, getting near the end of a process of consultation and discussion with its employees faltered. It made a critical error, and the error is simply the results that are written into Bill C-26.
It establishes by law that the federal Government of Canada-and for the most part it will be its managers who do it-will now have a legal and unilateral right to do certain things that it could not have done before.
It does not get that right out of a consensus from all of its employees or set of negotiations with its employees. It gets that right out of a law.
In my view, that law is fatally flawed. It will not work. It will give the government a legal right to do something

which, for practical purposes it cannot do, nor should it do.
I regret veiy much that the end of this long consultation process is the unilateral imposition of a law such as this one, for this is off on the wrong foot entirely and will bring heartache to a great many people who certainly do not deserve any more.
It is true that the principles put forward in this bill are roughly following a pattern, a pattern where the Government of Canada says to its employees: "Okay, we are in tough times here, but we do not want to talk to you any more. Now we are going to impose a law".
It did that last year when it tried to go through contract negotiations and impose by law, a settlement at that time. It is doing it again this year with this bill.
It did not work well during the course of contract negotiations; it will not work any better now. That lesson has to be learned by the Government of Canada and all of the members in here.
This is not the kind of thing that one can do successfully. You can cause a lot of pain. You can cause a lot of hardship. You can displace a great many of your employees, but you will not make the process of governing in this country more effective by the imposition of this kind of a law. That is why I oppose it.

Mr. Speaker, this is an opportunity to debate not only the bill which is before us today, Bill C-26, but also much of what has happened in the context of Public Service reform over the last several years of the current government.
Unfortunately, even as we debate this bill today, there are many across Canada who continue to hold in their minds an image of a federal Public Service which is somehow fat, overpaid, perhaps incompetent, and perhaps unresponsive to people in their times of need.
I think that it is important for the people of Canada to understand not only the kind of Public Service we have today in our country, but the history and traditions of that Public Service over the last number of years, really since it was formed in its present way in 1919.
We have today in the Public Service of Canada approximately the same number of federal public servants as there were in 1974 delivering a vastly increased

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
burden of responsibility and service to the people of Canada.
Well over one-half of them are employed outside the national capital region. Again, the image that somehow federal public servants are centered in the city of Ottawa and are pipe-smoking semi-retirees is a false and misleading one.
The Public Service of Canada delivers a whole variety of vital and important services to our people.
Surveys have shown that public servants are not well paid in comparison to many working groups in the private sector. They often perform functions which the private sector is incapable and unwilling to perform. As well, they perform a very important role in advising government on a daily basis. The traditions we have built up in the Canadian Public Service are fine and honourable traditions going back many decades.
We have had in the Public Service of Canada an understanding of the fact that it was an honour to serve the public, that the traditions of extending oneself on behalf of the citizens of the country was an honour in itself beyond simply earning a living. It was somehow a higher, nobler calling and often a calling which extended throughout one's working career.
Those traditions have been very important to the building of Canada as it is today. We have many well-known and important examples of public servants who have distinguished themselves in the service of our country.
Lester Pearson comes to mind as having been a civil servant who rose to the top office in this country, who in service to Canada won the Nobel Peace Prize.
It is critical at this time as we look at reform of the Public Service that we do so preserving the essential values and concerns that are at the heart of the Public Service as we have come to know it.
In the document Public Service 2000, Renewal of the Public Service in Canada some of these values have been set out. I think they have been well expressed.
Service to Canada and to Canadians, loyalty to the duly elected government, honesty, integrity, and nonpartisanship, prudence in the use of taxpayers' money, faithfulness to the principles of fairness and impartiality,
professionalism in carrying out their duties, and respect for ministers, other parliamentarians, members of the public and other members of the Public Service, these are the values which underlie this important institution in Canadian life.
So when we embark on a reform of it, the outcome of that reform is exceedingly important to our country. Not just because the Public Service delivers services like air traffic control and meat inspection to the people of Canada, important as those are, but because as Canada faces the very important challenges that confront us over the decade to come, we need the very best of our people, the sharpest minds, and the most innovative policymakers to be advising and directing in the policy-making of our country.
How is it that we are meant to face the challenges of internationalization without a Public Service devoted to solving those problems consisting of the very best and the very brightest.
It is crucial that at this point of renewal, of revitalization, we get it right. It is too important a task for us to fail to do it properly.
For that reason I find that I have to raise for myself at least, the question of whether this government at this time in its mandate is in a position to undertake this vital and crucial task.
We have a government-Mr. Speaker, you need only look to see-of ghosts in this country, ghosts because they have been deprived by their own unpopularity, by their own misguided policies, of the authority granted to them at the voting booths to continue to govern this country in an effective way.
We are confronted by a series of crucial problems, one of which is revitalization of the Public Service. This government of ghosts stumbles from problem to problem, clearly without the authority to make the important decisions that will set the course for this country for the years to come.
When we look at these ringing words of truth on values in the Public Service one wonders where are the ministers and what values do they pursue in carrying out their duties. The core of the problem, if there is a problem in the carrying out of the duties within the Public Service today, has been the deterioration of the morale of our public servants.

February 10, 1992
It being two o'clock p.m. the House will now proceed to Statements by Members pursuant to Standing Order 31.

subsubtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, at noon yesterday in Rouyn-Noranda, I met the regional president of the UPA for Abitibi-Temiscamingue, Mr. Jutras, and several members of his organization.
I have defended Quebec farmers for several months at our government meetings in Ottawa. Today we must intensify our efforts so that our farmers win the battle in GATT. We must accept no compromise on the four main pillars of agriculture: supply management, stabilization insurance for farm incomes, crop and farm insurance, farm credit and above all we must strengthen article XI of GATT.
As in past years, I strongly support the demands of our Canadian farmers.

Mr. Speaker, the announcement last week by the housing minister, reducing the amount required for down payments on first homes, first suggested by the Leader of the Opposition, is laudable and most appreciated by people on this side of the House. It is widely viewed as a positive step for people who would otherwise never achieve the dream of owning their own home.
My office has received a number of suggestions from the people of Halifax as to how the initiative might be improved. One idea is to expand the scope of the program to include those individuals who have owned a home previously but who have lost it. This is a request that is grounded in the fundamental tenet of fairness.
As the minister knows, these are difficult economic times. Many Canadians have not been able to keep pace with interest payments. Therefore, it would be fair to allow them the ability to re-enter the home market in a period of lower interest rates. This initiative could be subject to certain regulations to ensure that the government allows flexibility while maintaining the twin principles of deficit reduction and fiscal responsibility.
Once again I urge the minister to heed the calls of ordinary Canadians and expand his already admirable initiative.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians from across the land are getting involved in the political system.
Today at the standing joint committee on a renewed Canada my constituents had the opportunity to voice their opinions on the national stage. By expanding our horizons with new initiatives and ideas, we will forge a new beginning for this country where elected people in the House of Commons and the Senate will equally represent constituents from all regions of Canada.
This is a plan that will allow all of our resources to be utilized in a way that will maintain our strengths and freedoms; strengths and freedoms that have made Canada the envy of the world.

Mr. Speaker, the northern tax benefit plays a vital role in the development of Canada's north. It helps to offset the higher cost of living associated with northern Canada.
Recently the Reform Party has said that if elected they would take away the northern tax benefit. This shows that Preston Manning does not understand how important this tax initiative is for the northern economy. By eliminating the northern tax benefit, the Reform Party would hurt the fragile northern economy and would make it difficult to attract new residents to the north. By questioning the northern tax benefit, Preston Manning is showing his lack of vision for Canada's north.
I have received written resolutions from the councils of a number of northern communities, including Faro and Dawson in Yukon, Churchill and Leaf Rapids in

February 10, 1992
Manitoba and Nampa in Alberta which strongly support the northern tax benefit.
In Alberta the provincial Liberal and Conservative by-election candidates are both Reform Party members federally. However, in this House we must not pander to the narrow vision of the Reform Party. This government must renew its commitment to the northern tax benefit and it must do so in the upcoming budget.

Mr. Speaker, as the first ministers meet to discuss the economy, tens of thousands of Canadians will eat today, thanks only to food banks.
Hunger in Canada is a disgrace but still the Prime Minister refuses to visit a food bank and calls them "some sort of short-term thing". Gerard Kennedy of the Daily Bread Food Bank is on the front lines and says: "There is more hurt and extreme hardship out there than there has been in the last 25 years". Denial will not stop the reality of malnourished children who cannot learn and adults who become more depressed every day.
What is the government's plan for economic recovery? Why did this government miss the opportunity, from 1985 to 1990, to cut the deficit instead of bringing the economy to a halt?
We in the Official Opposition have shared our five point economic recovery plan with this government, including the plan for infrastructure development.
Let us put aside our partisan politics. Let us co-operate to put Canadians back to work and eliminate the need for permanent food banks in our society.

Mr. Speaker, the Winter Olympics opened this past weekend in Albertville, France. They have brought back fond memories of Calgary and the 1988 games.
This week we can all be proud of the Canadian athletes who are each going to reach for the highest standard of personal performance for themselves and for our country.
I have three friends and constituents who are each medal contenders in these Olympics. One of the best known carries the extra weight of high expectations on his shoulders as he competes in men's figure skating. Kurt Browning is three times a world champion and is favoured to excel again. He has already proved that he is the best in the world. We sincerely hope that his skill and conditioning serve him well in Albertville.
Our best wishes go out not just to Kurt, but to all the Canadian Olympians. May they do their physical best and may all Canadians share pride in their performance and recognize the tremendous personal contribution that each of them has made in order to represent us in these games.

Mr. Speaker, today I would like to say a few words to you on the Hibernia project. The federal government has invested or will invest over $1 billion in this big project without having done the necessary environmental studies. Nor has it taken the time required to assess the profitability of this project. Today we realize that Gulf Canada is withdrawing from the project.
Therefore, I ask the federal government, since there is still time, to withdraw from this project, which is considered unprofitable.

Mr. Speaker, today our colleague and friend, Marcel Prud'homme, is celebrating his 28th anniversary as a member of Parliament. He was elected for the first time on February 10, 1964 in a by-election.
Last night, the executive committee, board of directors, advisory board and general assembly of the Greek community all decided unanimously to declare him an honorary member of Montreal's Greek community in recognition of his services to Canada, Quebec and ethnic groups in Montreal, more particularly their community.
February 10,1992

Many of us had the opportunity last night to hear him speak at an evening reception in his honour.
Marcel, congratulations for these 28 years.
Hear, hear.

Mr. Speaker, when the free trade agreement with the United States was announced, many thought that one of the big losers would be the grape and wine industry.
However, with the help of the federal government and the Government of Ontario, the necessary restructuring of the industry took place in the Niagara region.
This year the results are becoming evident. For the first time in 12 years there is no surplus of crops, as all the grapes produced have been used by the industry. Domestic wine consumption has increased while the consumption of foreign wines has declined. In fact, international bodies have recognized the quality of Niagara wines, one example being Inniskillen Ice Wine.
The Niagara grape and wine industry is an example of what can be accomplished with quality products and the willingness to compete in the world without the need for a restrictive trade policy.

Mr. Speaker, over the past weekend more than 2,500 delegates gathered in Hamilton to elect a new leader of the Ontario Liberal Party.
The city of Hamilton, her people and the wonderful facilities again demonstrated that Hamilton is a most hospitable and wonderful community.
Thunder Bay is extremely proud that our own daughter, Lyn McLeod, was elected the leader of the Liberal Party. To quote from Lyn: "There will soon be a day when women in Canada will be able to seek high public office without gender being raised into question." Throughout the race she said her main goals would be to
revive the Ontario economy and the electorate's faith in the political process.
I am sure that Lyn McLeod will rule Ontario with an iron hand but always in a velvet glove. We all applaud her wonderful victory.

Mr. Speaker, hopefully today's economic meeting among first ministers will produce constructive initiatives by all concerned. There is one important move, however, that could be made by every premier, that being to harmonize provincial taxes with the federal GST program.
Two weeks ago a public lecture was delivered in Fredericton by economist Dr. William Milne, who holds the Vaughan Chair of Regional Economics at UNB. In his analysis of current economic circumstances, he was not particularly kind to any government and certainly had lots of criticism for federal financial policy.
However, he did address one issue strongly and clearly: the goods and services tax is an absolutely essential measure for the country; it is a major improvement over the old tax system that it replaced; and all provinces should harmonize their provincial sales tax systems with it.
Those are initiatives which could commence today. They would address the financial requirements of governments at all levels; they would simplify sales tax administration for companies, customers and consumers alike; they would dramatically dampen present incentives for cross-border shopping.

Mr. Speaker, this government has promised action to end violence against women over and over again.
Parliament passed a law declaring December 6 a national day of remembrance and action on violence against women.

February 10,1992
Ministers continually boast about the family violence initiative. Now it seems that funding to end violence, so proudly announced by this government, is being cut off before it can be used.
Five government departments recently made commitments of almost $40,000 to a conference called "Justice: Extending the Vision-A National Conference on Victimization and Recovery".
This conference is bringing together service providers who work every day to help women and children suffering from abuse and violence. Now this funding is in jeopardy just a few weeks before the conference is scheduled to start.
So many promises to end violence. Is that all we hear, words? As many Canadian women fear, is it simply just talk?
I call on the government to reinstate this funding today and to keep faith with the women and children of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I recently conducted a survey in my riding of Halton-Peel and thousands of constituents responded.
Doug Rowan of Caledon East writes me:
I am 49, struggling with a new business, but expect things to improve financially and everything else will follow along. I am blessed with a close and supportive family and we all work at keeping it so. The country will rally together finally this summer, to keep Quebec in but not without difficulty and continued grumbling. The economy will rally but ever so slowly. The future will brighten if we start talking positively in every respect.
Ed Ford-King of Cheltenham writes me:
I believe in a strong central government with the courage to make and stick by hard decisions, that concentrates on and believes in education and training, that develops an environment for opportunity and growth, that believes in the rule of law. I am saddened by the party system which lies and bribes with giveaways to gain power. I am sickened by a political system with little or no fiscal responsibility, where different governments go in opposite fiscal directions. I seek a political, fiscal environment in which one can grow in safety and with pride as a Canadian.
I look forward to reporting on my other constituents' views.

Mr. Speaker, who is George Bush and why is he saying these nasty things about Canadian medicare?
George Bush is the best known beneficiary of a government medical care system, so why does he want Americans to believe that the hopelessly expensive U.S. system-where 34 million people have no insurance and 50 million people have only partial coverage-is somehow better than Canada's?
Bush is complaining that there are six month delays for heart surgery in British Columbia but the fact is that most critical cases receive surgery within two weeks. That is not bad when you consider those 34 million Americans without medical insurance who would not get needed heart surgery even when they wait a lifetime.
And who is Frank McKenna, and why is he now advocating an American, two-tier means tested health care system? Is he the Republican party's Liberal echo in Canada?

Mr. Speaker, a great many Canadians firmly believe that Canadian corporations are not paying their fair share of taxes. Many if not all of the same Canadians are concerned about jobs being lost and transferred to the United States.
One reason that businesses move to the United States is taxes. Prior to 1986 the average U.S. corporate tax rate was 51 per cent while the comparable Canadian rate was 48 per cent. Today the U.S. rate is approximately 39 per cent compared with a 42 per cent Canadian rate. Our corporate tax rate, previously slightly lower than the United States, is now higher. When withholding taxes, as they affect Canadian subsidiaries of U.S. corporations are taken into account, Canadian rates are substantially higher than the U.S. rates.
No wonder we are losing jobs. We do not have a level playing field. As far as corporate taxes and calls for even higher corporate taxes are concerned, we appear to be our own worst enemy.
February 10, 1992

Mr. Speaker, adult illiteracy is not just a problem for the Third World, it is damaging our economic performance as well as the performance of many of the world's developed countries.
An international survey has pointed out that up to one-third of adults in some countries may be hindered in their work by inadequate reading and writing skills. A Canadian study has pointed out that 38 per cent of Canadian adults tend to avoid situations that require reading because of their inadequate reading skills. Just a couple of years ago a Southam survey found that illiteracy is costing the Canadian taxpayer $10 billion a year.
In September, 1988 the government made an announcement of $22 million for five years to fight illiteracy. This represents an investment of less than $4.50 per illiterate adult in this country. The government has instituted a tax on books and other reading materials. It is now time to take serious action on illiteracy.

What is happening now is not enough. It is inadequate. Nothing has changed.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister.
For months opposition members, business leaders, labour leaders, even bank presidents, have been telling the government that their economic policies are wrong and are leading the country in the wrong direction.
In this month's issue of Inside Magazine a former Conservative MP and the party's former finance critic says that the current policies of the Department of Finance and the Bank of Canada are "not only ludicrous, but extremely counter-productive, wrong, wrongheaded, unrealistic and bordering on the tragic".
Oral Questions
Does the Acting Prime Minister agree with this prominent Conservative's assessment of the government's financial policy and does he realize that what we need is a new economic direction for this country?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the short answer to the question is no.
The premiers of this country, together with the Prime Minister, are meeting today to discuss the short and medium-term economic situation in this country. I might remind the hon. member, as she had the opportunity this morning to listen to the premiers as they made their presentations in a very reasonable and thoughtful way, that there are differences of opinion, that there are different approaches to the situation here in Canada. Some premiers are supporting the approach of the federal government, others would like to see us take a little different line. But, generally speaking, I think they are supportive of our work in getting the deficit under control, getting it down, getting interest rates down, having a dollar that is competitive and getting people back to work on full-time meaningful employment.

This morning at that same conference, Mr. Speaker, we saw 2,000 farmers demonstrate to appeal to this government about article XI of GATT. According to the publicity in today's newspapers, thousands and thousands of farmers are counting on this government to do its best to protect and even improve article XI of GATT. Therefore I ask the Acting Prime Minister: When will he be able to protect the interests of 100,000 farmers who depend on article XI of GATT?

Mr. Speaker, the position that the Government of Canada has taken in the GATT negotiations is the position that was developed with the stakeholders, with the farmers in Canada. Our position has not changed. We developed that position jointly. Our negotiators are attempting to have that position accepted wherever they are able to find an ear.

February 10,1992
Oral Questions
The Prime Minister has been involved in discussions with leaders. I have been involved in discussions with my counterparts. The minister of trade has been involved in discussions with his counterparts. We will continue to put forward the case that we developed with the stakeholders in supply management.

Mr. Speaker, the unfortunate thing is that while the government is publicly claiming it is moving to strengthen article XI of the GATT, it is privately moving to prepare for tariffication and in fact discussions in that regard have already occurred.
My question is for the Acting Prime Minister. The Acting Prime Minister should know that Canada is not alone in its intention to strengthen article XI of the GATT. In fact, the government could find allies with Japan, Norway, Israel, Switzerland and other countries who are willing to help us in our battle.
Will this government not, at the very least, develop a common position with other countries to protect the
100,000	farmers whose livelihood is on the line in these negotiations?
I welcome the suggestions put forward by the House leader of the opposition. We have met with those who support Canada's position. They include Japan, Israel, Norway, Korea and Switzerland.
We know that.

If you know that, as the member says from his seat, then why are you suggesting that we should seek it? We have been involved with those five countries. We led a demarche into Mr. Dunkel to try to gain the position that we share with those six countries.
I can only say to the hon. member she is absolutely wrong in her preface, we have not initiated discussions on tariffication. We never looked at the text to see if the numbers were going to be there until I had consulted with the provincial ministers of agriculture and with the supply managed agencies themselves. They said: "Yes, see what those numbers are.". We looked at those numbers.
Oh, oh.

They say "oh". Ask any supply management leader if he authorized us to look at the numbers. We sent the numbers to the supply management groups and now, we are waiting for them to say: "are those the numbers" because we cannot negotiate until we know what harm will be caused. The hon. member should know that.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister. The Canadian supply management system has been in place and has worked both for the benefit of the consumers and the producers in Canada. The dairy, egg and poultry producers of this country have not and are not part of the world's surplus problem.
Why are these producers being asked to be part of the solution when they are not part of the problem?

The
hon. member knows full well that the agencies, developed with the Government of Canada and with the provinces, the position that the Government of Canada is putting forward, that article XI should be strengthened and clarified. It is not something that the Government of Canada, on the side, made a decision on. We consulted directly with the agencies, the supply management groups, developed the position that Canada had at the outset, developed the position that Canada had in December and continues to have to this day.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the the same minister. Mr. Lowen, an Alberta turkey producer says that as a result of the Dunkel proposals at the GATT, that: "Everything that I ever worked for in my whole life will be trashed."
Another rally in Ottawa today of 2,000 farmers agrees with Mr. Lowen. Knowing all of this, why has the government not carried out and published an impact assessment of the Dunkel proposals to GATT?

The
hon. member asks why the government has not changed its position. We have not changed our position because we developed the position with the supply management agencies. The supply management agencies have not changed their position and therefore the position of the Government of Canada is that article XI shall be strengthened and clarified under the GATT.

Mr. Speaker, the first ministers are meeting today. The Prime
February 10, 1992

Minister is calling for co-operation. The finance minister says he is willing to look at reallocations in his budget to help the economy.
With housing starts down dramatically again today for another month, this economy badly needs help. Federal money for infrastructure would create 63,000 new jobs this year.
I want to ask the Acting Prime Minister if the federal government will reallocate money for this kind of program by cancelling the $100,000 capital gains tax exemption, an unjust tax break that increases the deficit by $2 billion a year and gives three-quarters of its benefits to the rich in this country.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
The hon. member would be interested to know, Mr. Speaker, that of those who claim the $100,000 capital gains tax exemption, about 60 per cent of them earn under $50,000 a year. Those are the facts.
The other thing is that the small business exemption, the farm exemption and the $100,000 capital gains exemption help create employment.
The hon. member should understand that. That is investing in the Canadian economy. That is not the area that we necessarily should be looking at.
But I can tell the hon. member this. The Prime Minister and the Minister of Finance are meeting today with the first ministers. They are going to listen to all the suggestions that are made. They will be having discussions which I am sure will be carried on in the weeks ahead. When the budget is presented the hon. member will see this government's position for the next fiscal year and how we are going to handle the financial affairs of this country.

Mr. Speaker, I have the taxation statistics here for the most recent year and they show that 76 per cent of the benefits of the capital gains tax exemption go to people making individually over $60,000 a year. That is not fair. That is not right. Over a quarter go to people making over $250,000 a year. There has to be change.
I want to ask about another area of economic policy. The United States is using bully tactics on auto industry trade. U.S. firms and unions are pushing their workers to buy U.S. made cars at the expense of Canadian made cars in clear defiance of the auto pact.
Oral Questions
I want to ask the government, given news today, that we have also seen a drop in auto sales in the most recent month, will the government protest as strongly as possible against these unfair discriminatory U.S. actions?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have to tell my hon. friend that first of all he is wrong in terms of automobiles and motor vehicles. Sales have been up the last two months on trucks and vans and they have been up in a material way.
More important, the hon. member fought tooth and nail against the whole idea of a free trade agreement which would include a dispute settlement mechanism. Under article 18 of the FTA we have a dispute settlement mechanism which allows us, when we are faced with protectionist pressures in the United States that are unfair, or incorrect, to bring them, as we are in fact bringing an automobile case that we announced on January 5 to the dispute settlement mechanism, to a panel which comprises one Canadian, one American and a neutral chairman. We have equality with the Americans when we have a dispute. This is far better than we ever had before the FTA.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, each time a dairy farm dies, part of Canada dies too. These are the words of Canadian dairy farmers today, a truth which can be repeated by all Canadian farmers.
Twenty-six million Canadians cannot feed themselves. As my colleague said before, Japan, Switzerland and other countries want to strengthen article XI. Where is Canada?
The credibility of this minister's statements are questioned by farmers. Why is this government not adamant that supply management is the best system for Canadian dairy and poultry producers?

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I say once again to my hon. colleague that the position of the Government of Canada is that article XI should be clarified and strengthened. We have tried to

February 10,1992
Oral Questions
find allies to reinforce that important position that the Government of Canada has in the GATT negotiations. We have, along with five other countries, joined forces to try to convince another 102 that that is the way that we should be going because Canada knows that the system that we have under the existing article XI has not distorted international trade. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the survival of our food production capacity is a matter of national security. Europeans are very aware of this. Because of the government's weakness in supporting article XI, 100,000 farmers in the dairy, egg and poultry industry are at risk.
Does the government have a strategy and can it show how, and at what cost, it intends to meet the Canadian demand for dairy products and poultry, in the event that
100,000	Canadian producers are wiped out?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am rather surprised at the hon. member's reaction, when we consider that Canada's position has always been to maintain marketing boards-as explained in the document we tabled in Geneva in April 1990, almost two years ago-and that our position has not changed.
I think we have supported farm producers in all areas, including supply management. I would urge the hon. member and her colleagues in the other opposition parties to join us in defending the position taken by the government, which is that of our farm producers.
As I said before, Mr. Speaker, this is no time for divisiveness. It is time for all political parties, including the opposition, and all governments, federal and provincial, to pull together and show the world that Canada is serious about the position it is defending in Geneva. I believe that would probably be more helpful to our farm producers than raising fears that have no basis in fact.

Mr. Speaker, in the absence of the trade minister, my question is directed to the Minister of National Health and Welfare.
On January 14 the government agreed to a GATT proposal to extend drug patent protection to 20 years, thereby endangering the Canadian generic industry at home.
Why did government officials write a letter, of which I have a copy, to one of the largest generic firms, Apotex, on Friday, January 10, seeking its input when, only after one full working day and without any response, the government completely gave in to the GATT recommendation? Why did the government not honestly seek the advice of the generic industry and Canadians on such a fundamentally important matter?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, to my knowledge, the minister of trade said that he did consult the generic industry. I believe that the position was and remains that in terms of research and development, on the question of the compulsory licence, we consider that the decision will be good for Canada.
I met with the ministers of health from all provinces, except Quebec. We had the commitment to consider all the implications of the decision. We are in touch with the provinces. We believe that at the health level, the cost of drugs, for example, will remain reasonable, as Bill C-22 proved.
The member said years ago that there would be sky-rocketing prices. There were not. We have the same kind of approach to reality today.

Mr. Speaker, the government insults the intelligence of Canadians when it says it has consulted, when it writes a letter on Friday, does not wait for a response and moves on it Tuesday. That is just shameful.
I ask the same minister this.
Given that the generic industry employs some 3,000 Canadians, invests all of its research and development in the country and has had a stabilizing effect on the price of prescription drugs, why will the government not seek a better deal and balance between the foreign based
February 10,1992

multinational pharmaceutical companies and the home grown Canadian generic industry on behalf of and in the interests of Canadians?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I said before that the policy and the decision have been made to strengthen the development of research and development in Canada first.
Second, the member says that the generics will not be able to continue their operations. I tell my friend that in the United States there is no compulsory licence for generic pharmaceuticals.

speechtext: The debate is on the main motion and the amendment of Mrs. Catterall. When the motion was adjourned at 2 p.m., the hon. member for Ottawa South still had 11 minutes left.

Mr. Speaker, at 2 p.m., I was saying that the main problem with the Public Service right now is the public servants' morale. This problem was very well explained when the report of the task force on services to the public, one of the studies done by Public Service 2000, was tabled.

The Public Service 2000 task force report refers to the following: "Recent research reveals low morale among sector managers when compared with their private sector counterparts.
