You might wonder why this is relevant to the reforms that are under way. I submit that in attempting through this process of Public Service reform and revitalization to address issues of service to the public, a failure to deal with underlying causes of low morale in the Public Service dooms to failure this reform. This task force, in its report on service to the public, a very interesting document, highlights the characteristics of a client centred organization.
Trying to focus on what reforms are necessary to make the Public Service of Canada more client centred, one of the characteristics which I have highlighted is: "These organizations", that is client centred ones, "treat their managers and staff well, engendering attitudes which
encourage empowerment, participation, delegation and trust.
If you accept the premise of PS 2000, the government is trying to get people lower down in the bureaucracy to take responsibility for things that are before them; to become accountable, yes, but to make decisions; as Glassco said many years ago, to make managers able to manage. If that kind of responsibility is going to be taken, the managers and the people with whom they work must feel part of the process.
Surely in embarking on a reform of the Public Service which was intended to make it more client focused, it would have been wise had that reform not been undertaken through a process of study which was entirely top down.
When you look at the issues that have given rise to what is currently a chronic and very continuing state of low morale in the Public Service, you ask yourself how a top down study such at this one, together with the kinds of problems that are compounding the problems that the Public Service is experiencing, will ever lead to a more effective, efficient Public Service.
Let me explain what I mean by those problems.
At present if you look at the people at the lower ranks of the Public Service, many of whom are my constituents, and you consider how the government provoked a labour action last year which led to a great deal of dissatisfaction and mistrust between those employees and their employer, you understand that it will be veiy difficult to rebuild that morale.
These people are low paid. They are the least empowered, if you like, of all of the government employees and very often they are the people with whom the public deals. In asking the Public Service to accept restraint in wages, which I think it was more than prepared to do, in choosing not to ask it to restrain its wage increases but in offering it a zero per cent increase in a year in which inflation was running on average around 5.5 per cent, the government was so unreasonable as to constitute a breach of trust with the very people we are now asking to be more responsive and more considerate in then-dealings with the public and more determined to provide more for less in the context of greater efficiencies.
February 10, 1992

At the other end of the spectrum, at the senior end of the spectrum, you have a different phenomenon occurring. Over the course of this past few years in government we have seen the erosion of the very important principle of ministerial responsibility. We have seen it in two cases. We have seen it first of all in 1989 in the case of the budget leak, in which the Minister of Finance proved himself unwilling to take responsibility for the fact that portions of his budget were leaked in advance. Instead he chose to stand in the House of Commons, as did the Prime Minister of Canada, and say that it was caused by a criminal act-complete abrogation of his duty as a minister.
Then, more recently, we had the case of the ministers of external affairs and immigration in the affair known as the A1 Mashat affair. In that case again ministers of the Crown not only failed to take on their ministerial responsibility but were willing to name public servants in public as being responsible for things that went on in their departments.
Kenneth Kemaghan, a political scientist at Brock University and respected authority on public administration, was quoted in The Ottawa Citizen in June 1991:
It is extremely important that ministers do not publicly name and blame whoever is at fault. This is to preserve both the anonymity and political neutrality of public servants. Loyalty, after all, is a two-way street. By tradition, public servants are not permitted to speak out in their own defence against ministerial criticism.
In commenting on this affair, the Montreal Gazette wrote:
What is indefensible is the spineless attempt by the ministers involved to cover their own tracks in this affair.
The Montreal Gazette says that the ministers involved:
-did not behave like ministers responsible by parliamentary tradition for all that happens in their ministries. They behaved more like cockroaches scurrying for cover when the lights come on. They all denied prior knowledge of Mr. Mashat's immigration and deplored his admission. They dissembled, they changed stories, they pointed the finger at others, they blamed and named civil servants.
In the face of the conduct of this government, in the face of the fact that it has lost credibility and authority as a result of its incompetence and unwillingness to listen to the people of Canada, how on earth can it come forward with a package of reforms such as Public Service 2000, with a bill such as Bill C-26, and expect not only
Government Orders
the people of Canada but particularly the members of the Public Service of Canada to take it seriously?
I suggest that it is unthinkable that this package of reforms, with its top down approach and coming from a government that has lost its authority over its own employees, can ever hope to solve the problems the Public Service confronts. It seems to me that the suggestions made by the public accounts committee, when it reviewed the PS 2000 documents earlier on, to refer the discussion papers to a House of Commons committee, was the correct approach. What we need is a study not only by the senior bureaucrats themselves but one by the Parliament of Canada into the Public Service to help us to understand how that Public Service can be best redirected at the end of the 20th century to meet the hopes and needs of Canadians.
It is not enough just to leave it in the hands of the ministers and their senior deputies. It is far too important a task.
I would like to add my voice to that of my colleague from Ottawa West who moved an amendment to the government's motion asking that this bill be pre-studied. Perhaps in that study there will be the opportunity once and for all for parliamentarians to figure out what kind of games are being played by the government in their continuing practice of contracting out functions that in the past have been performed honourably and competently by the Public Service of Canada.
The fact that this continues without any clear accounting system, enabling us to know what is being spent on contracting out, continues to be one of the unproclaimed scandals of the present government. This issue has to be examined under the bright lights of parliamentary and media scrutiny.
I do not think we can support this bill. This bill, bringing forward as it does a few elements of a very broad and very important study, is inadequate to be voted on in the House of Commons without a complete and thorough study of a lot of the principles and the basic concepts that underlie the Public Service today.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to say that my colleague from Ottawa is always here for his constituents, many of them being public servants. I know that the Public Service tends to be battered from one end of this country to

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
another, especially in ridings like my own where we do not have a lot of public servants. Quite often when service to the public is at fault or it is slow or there are problems in process, it is always the Public Service that tends to get the brunt of the criticism.
We are in a very difficult economic period where the demand on the Public Service is probably twice as high as it would be during a period of a good economy, so there is even more pressure on our public servants, those people dedicated to the service of Canada. They are constantly being bombarded with very difficult situations.
My question for my colleague relates to the number of people in the Public Service. I notice that the numbers in the Public Service right now are the same numbers we had in the early seventies. I think my hon. member, having a large riding of public servants, could be more specific.
I cannot imagine an organization like General Motors, any factory or any organization that was growing and meeting the needs of the market, having in 1991 the same number of people as they had in the early seventies and still expect to succeed in the quality of public service that was required.
Does my colleague not think that that sort of constricted action, that grinding down of numbers and support services within the Public Service Alliance of Canada not only affects the morale of the country but also the quality of service that ultimately we are all elected to provide through them?

Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank my colleague from Broadview-Greenwood for his question. All of us as members of Parliament from all parties have experienced the effects of the downsizing of the federal Public Service. We experience it on a daily basis in our constituency offices as we endeavour to help constituents who are trying to deal with whatever their problems may be with the federal government.
Recently we found in the area of income security the difficulty of getting information from income security offices on constituents' pension matters, on their Canada Pension Plan, Old Age Security and so on.
I know we all experience, especially in urban centres, the incredible delays in dealing with immigration matters where we have months and months going by while we wait for information on very basic and simple cases. I have followed up on letters I have sent as a member of Parliament to the minister of immigration for which replies were not given within a year of writing. This is how badly backed up the service has become in the Public Service of Canada. The reason is clear. When you look at the number of person years, which is essentially the number of people who work in the federal government, they have declined from about 258,000 in 1983-1984 down to 221,000 in 1990-1991. This is about the level it was in 1974.
All Canadians appreciate the fact that the federal government is being called upon to provide more and better and faster service to the people of Canada than it was almost 20 years ago, yet the people that are actually engaged in doing that are fewer in number.
That is also true in the policy development area. I mentioned earlier we are confronting a large number of very significant policy issues, partly the economic ones that I referred to of internationalization that is occurring, but also we are going through in our society a very dramatic demographic shift as the population ages. By the year 2040, regardless essentially of what we do with immigration, our population in Canada will decline.
We are in critical need, I think, of the very best minds that Canada has to offer in the area of policy development at the government level. Instead of twisting and squeezing and trying to grind this number of public servants down, ostensibly an effort to save expense, we are losing out on the opportunity to have the very best policy development occurring.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to speak in support of Bill C-26 that is now before the House. I do not at all pretend, as the hon. member for Ottawa South just did, that with this bill we are trying to decrease the number of civil servants or trying to denigrate them. I think that they render all Canadians valuable services.
February 10, 1992

I have often had to deal with officials of the Public Service of Canada and I can tell you, Mr. Speaker, that I am very satisfied with it. Most of them provide very professional and competent services and make the work of all of us much easier.
The bill before us today is not meant to diminish the number of our public servants or to degrade them; it is primarily intended to make them a little more mobile in their tasks and in their career progression. The Public Service of Canada now has 71 job classifications, which make it practically impossible for public servants of a particular rank and qualifications to move up to higher levels even though they may well be qualified to do so.
Basically, this bill is to allow that flexibility, to be fairer to our public servants, especially those in positions traditionally held by women, since in some categories, women cannot advance and it is practically impossible for them to apply for another type of employment with other qualifications that would give them the opportunity to provide Canadians with very good services and at the same time use their skills.
So I must support this bill because it will make the government more efficient by being able to obtain competent people from other sectors and assign them where they are needed and because it is fairer to public servants, who can apply for positions they could not before.
Therefore I do not at all understand the opposition's arguments against this bill, since it is meant to upgrade our public servants. Nothing in the bill says that public servants do not do a good job or could be used, as someone just said, to denigrate or subordinate them. That is certainly not our intention-quite the contrary, I think.
At the same time as it recognizes their skills, this bill can help them advance, because you have to put yourself in a public servant's position. If they really want to give their fellow citizens good service, they should be given the opportunity to do so. Those who are competent must not be limited.
So that is the purpose of the bill and I can only support it, Mr. Speaker.

Mr. Speaker, the amendment before the House proposes: That Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service
Government Orders
Employment act, the Public Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada, be not now read a second time but that it be read a second time this day six months hence.
This is a striking example of a government bill that must be examined in depth by this House, by all members interested in this issue, in order to improve it, Mr. Speaker, and to change its principle as well as its implementation and substance. Mr. Speaker, I deeply regret that the government did not follow the advice of the public accounts committee of this House which, a year ago, strongly recommended to the government the referral of this bill or of a draft bill to a Committee of the Whole.
Mr. Speaker, it has taken 25 years to bring significant changes before this House. If we go back 25 years, we notice that when the original act was drafted, all the parties were involved in the process. This process did not involve only the government. No. All the political parties had been involved in order to ensure a fair examination of the Public Service Employment Act, and to ensure that all parliamentarians be aware of the importance of a Public Service accountable to the public at large and to this House, as well as responsible in its administration.
Now we have a majority government that tables, on second reading, a bill which, as we know, could be passed in its present form, given the number of government members. Mr. Speaker, I deeply regret this situation, because I am convinced that the experience of the members of the opposition, as well as of those of the government, could have been beneficial and positive. We are therefore in the difficult position of proposing an amendment that asks the House to defer this discussion for six months precisely so that we can have this parliamentary exercise, so that we can examine the principle and the substance of the bill before passing it.
As I was saying, this bill is important for civil servants, but it is also important for Canadians. Since it was elected in 1984, the attitude of this government, the Conservative government, toward its employees, makes almost mandatory a complete revitalization of the Canadian Public Service. One only has to take a look at the numerous reports that were tabled, here in this House, or that were ordered by these royal commissions of inquiry, to know about proposed changes to improve the

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
Public Service. I refer hon. members to the Glassco report, in 1957-that is going back a long way-by the royal commission on economic perspectives in Canada; the Finkelman report, that many of us know because we spent several months with its author examining the scope of the proposals to amend the Public Service Staff Relations Act; the Lambert royal commission in March 1979, again on financial management and accountability; the d'Avignon report, in September 1979, by a special committee on management and the merit principle; the McDonald report in August 1985, by a commission which again studied the economic union and the development prospects for Canada. All those reports Mr. Speaker, without any exception, proposed numerous solutions, some of them very interesting, that were often forgotten and totally ignored by the governments.
And now we are faced with the implementation of another report. This one is called Public Service 2000, with all its advantages and shortcomings, praised largely by members of the government and criticized by everybody else, mostly by the unions, employees and your humble servant.
The synopsis of the document on the renewal of the Public Service of Canada says, and I quote from the briefing notes we received: "What is different about Public Service 2000 is that it is led from within by those who must implement its results". We are told that public servants were involved. I know some were.
There would certainly be fewer critics if the government had taken the advice of the public accounts committee which I have the privilege to chair which had recommended or strongly suggested submitting the working paper to a special committee of the House on a proposed reform of the Public Service of Canada, well before tabling amendments in the House. We as members were excluded from the consultation process and from any direct involvement in drafting or improving this bill.
There would probably be fewer critics, Mr. Speaker, if the government had stood by its previous commitment to consider only amendments approved by representatives of employees and senior management, as reliable critics.
Consider some of the changes. Selection according to merit, which is the prevailing standard today, means that
a person is hired for a job in the Public Service according to merit. In other words, the person best qualified to do the work gets the job.
According to clause 10(2), instead of using the merit principle exclusively, in future the commission may use measures or standards based not on merit alone but also on comparative tests of candidates. In other words, so and so is better suited to the job for the time being, even if he does not win on merit.
We are told there will be regulations to ensure impartiality, to ensure that people do not revert to nepotism by appointing friends or relatives. What will those regulations be like? I don't know. Will they enhance or detract from the merit principle? I don't know. There is a possibility that not the best candidate is selected but the one that suits the manager.
That is what some people have said, and I think that until we have some clear and specific answers, those claims are justified. The unions told me this measure could be used as an excuse for favouritism and all kinds of harassment, including sexual harassment. Mr. Speaker, we don't want to go back to that. We don't want that.
In the case of temporary employees, a new clause would be added to allow the Public Service Commission to appoint any person for a period not exceeding 90 days. An extension could be granted, not exceeding 125 days a year, in the same department or any other part of the Public Service.
Many people, myself included, believe that continual employee turnover and lack of continuity could lead to poorer service rather than the improvement sought.
Some clauses deal with the organization of the Public Service, of the allocation of positions in it and their classification. Mr. Speaker, I have been talking about this issue of job classification for 12 years. These issues will not be subject to arbitration. Nevertheless, this same government in 1984 promised as firmly as it could and as often as it could that job classification would be negotiable, Mr. Speaker. It did not keep its word. We have proof in Bill C-26 today. Even Mr. Mulroney, the leader of the Progressive Conservative Party, promised in 1984 to make staffing and classification negotiable.
February 10, 1992

Mr. Speaker, many of the proposed changes will eventually have to be covered in regulations. What makes it difficult for members here to pass this bill is that we cannot assess the impact of many of its provisions. It is not a bill that is easy to read, I agree. It covers complex legislation. The staff relations act, Mr. Speaker, is hard to know. You almost have to have been involved with it for 18 or 19 years to begin to get a feel for it.
Let us return, Mr. Speaker, to the primary purpose of Public Service 2000: to give public servants and managers more power; to give Canadians top-quality services. According to the authors of this reorganization plan, PS2000, Public Service 2000, as it is called, and Bill C-26, if I go by the material given to us, were to increase to the government's credibility-please note-and to give greater importance to serving the public.
This morning-
-we heard the parliamentary secretary say that public servants should spend less time serving systems and more time serving citizens. I agree with that. But let us see if indeed that is the result of this proposal.

What this bill should do is streamline a Public Service that has become too complex as a result of administrative red tape. I will give an example, Mr. Speaker, which you may think is rather far-fetched, but just the same: One day, a Public Service employee is asked to go and get a bottle of vinegar from government storage. It cost $30, Mr. Speaker, to take a taxi and go and get a bottle of vinegar that probably cost two or three dollars. Thirty dollars to get a bottle of vinegar, when he could have bought a bottle at the corner store, had he had the authority to do so. But that would have been against the rules! That bottle of vinegar had to come from a vinegar depot!
Mr. Speaker, that is the kind of story that makes Canadians somewhat cynical and is reminiscent of all the red tape that used to exist. When he appeared before the public accounts committee, the Auditor General suggested, and you will find this in the seventh report dated November 6, 1990, and I quote: "The current legislative and administrative framework is not adapted to the
Government Orders
environment and challenges facing the Public Service today-the need to eliminate unreasonable constraints, devolving more meaningful authority to departments and front-line managers, while ensuring proper rendering of accounts". There are references to increased delegation of authority. I think that is a sensible objective.
If I refer to the 1991 report of the Auditor General tabled recently, just before Christmas as a matter of fact, here is what I read: "An area of difficulty for past efforts at management reform appears to have been the absence of concrete proposals for moving from "here" to "there", for managing the process of change." Amendments to Bill C-26 are being put forward, but read this legislation carefully. Where are these concrete proposals for an efficient implementation? The Auditor General says further, and I quote: "The white paper on PS 2000 raises concern about excessive, detailed controls, but does not provide enough indication of the controls for government that are both essential and cost-effective." That is on page 26 of the annual report. He goes on to say that "any formal assessment of due regard to efficiency must rely on information about cost and performance."
Let me give you an example, Mr. Speaker, because I feel we should try to focus on this point. I will take the example of contracting out, in a department I am familiar with, the Secretaiy of State, and a function I know well, translation. At present, an employee maybe laid off by reason of lack of work or the discontinuance of a function. The bill before us will enable us to lay off an employee whose services are no longer required by reason of lack of work or the transfer of work outside the Public Service, in other words contracted out.
Such an amendment was deemed necessary by government following a November 1990 appeal judgment by the Federal Court upholding a Staff Relations Commission decision that government had violated a collective agreement when it filled 278 clerk positions in Revenue Canada by contracting out. The judge said that he thought it was not correct to say that the services of an employee whose work had been contracted out were no longer needed for lack of work or because a function had been eliminated. His services were no longer required because the function had been given to outside contrac-

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
tors. The task still had to be done and the function continued to exist.
Mr. Speaker, I see you signaling me that I have no more than one minute left. In the field of translation, Mr. Speaker, in 1985,1 think that 19 per cent of the work was contracted out. In 1989-90, it was 35 per cent and I am told that today, 50 per cent is to be contracted out. Where are the rules for accountability, Mr. Speaker? I know for a fact that officials now have a document for the decentralization of translation services because the departments are to be given the responsibility for administering this service.
Mr. Speaker, I ask you: Where is this document? Why do we not have it before us here in the House? Why can we members of Parliament not have it? I know that it exists. This document explains what the decentralization is about. It is important to know who will decide to privatize or contract out a service which it is this government's responsibility to provide as a servant of the state. I do not have all the information, Mr. Speaker, so I must tell you in conclusion that I cannot support this bill until it is reviewed and thoroughly studied by members of this House from all parties so that we can study this matter seriously fully documented and come to a consensus.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened with great interest to the remarks of my hon. friend from Ottawa-Vanier who, I think all members of the House would recognize, has a very strong interest in this area, representing a very large number of public servants. There were a couple of observations that he made which I would like to comment on and then in turn invite his comments.
One has to do with the provision in this bill dealing with short-term contracting of up to three months and possibly renewable. I think it is important to note that it is difficult to recognize what workloads will be at any given time. From time to time within the Public Service, as within industry, workloads become particularly heavy and it is necessary to bring somebody in to assist in the short term. I would suggest that in such circumstances it makes more sense to go out and get somebody who can
perform the task necessary and carry on. If a full-scale competition were required each time somebody needed to bring in a little bit of assistance, the need may well have passed before the competition was completed.
I think what we have in the bill here is the application of common sense. I think it is important to note that such casual employees would not become regular employees by entry through competition in the regular sense.
The other point has to do with subsection 10(2), which my hon. friend addressed. I see this whole bill as an attempt to inject a little more practicality and common sense. My hon. friend suspects, as did some earlier speakers in the New Democratic Party, some kind of surreptitious motive by the government. I think what we really have here is an attempt to apply common sense to the process. I think that is what subsection 10(2) does as well.
We have never really had an adequate definition of merit as opposed to competence in the assessment of circumstances. My hon. friend represents a large number of public servants in the Ottawa area. I represent a relatively small number of public servants in departments like Fisheries and Oceans, Canada Employment, CEIC and so on. It is very important to us that, for example, not just paper qualifications be taken into consideration when assessing people for promotions but, whether they know the area. Are they familiar? Do they understand the lifestyle and the priorities of people in a particular area?
Those things might not reflect themselves in paper qualifications. On the other hand, they are very critical in determining the competence of an individual.
The last point I will make with regard to that are the circumstances, for example, in which a job has been reclassified. Does it make sense to go to the cost, the time and the energy to have somebody reapply for their own job when they have a demonstrated competence in it?
I will stop at that and perhaps my hon. friend would like to comment.

Mr. Speaker, that is exactly the kind of debate I want. That is the kind of debate parliamentarians should have.
February 10, 1992

I brought out two or three points. I have another 25 points I could possibly bring out.
The member says that we do not have an adequate definition of merit. I have. The Public Service Commission is being attacked right now by his bill, in my view. I may be wrong. I have been wrong before. I am looking for some advice, some possible debate with the government members and those specialists in the field to make sure that the merit principle as I know it means that you get the job on merit, you can do it better than anybody else, and not because you know somebody or because you have better connections than the next guy. That is the merit principle as far as I am concerned.
I must say that I am satisfied with the annual report before this House by the Public Service Commission. I have been satisfied in the 19 years that I have been here that the Public Service Commission has addressed that question, has impartially administered that principle, that system.
I am worried now because the commission is being weakened. Look at clause 29 and look at clause 27. A new position is being created. I want to read it because it is important: "The Clerk of the Privy Council and secretary to the cabinet is the head of the Public Service".
Who is he? He is a nominee of the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister apolitical, non-partisan? Come on.
"He will table a report on the state of the Public Service in each fiscal year for the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister shall cause a copy of the report to be laid before each House of Parliament on any of the first 15 days on which that House is sitting after the Prime Minister receives it".
My concern is to make sure the Public Service of Canada is apolitical, non-partisan, chosen on merit, and not on the basis of who you know in the Privy Council and if you happen to be a friend of the system. I think that is wrong.
That is why I am concerned on that point. That is the merit principle.
Regarding the question of term employees, I do not have any quarrel with term employees. They do not have any quarrels with our position. They would like to be treated like human beings.
Government Orders
If I read the bill properly they are going to have a nomination for 90 days with a possible extension to 125 days within the same department. Some people have said you can go on and on and this can be a continuous rotation in every department: "We will move our friends after 90 days to 125 days. We will move them throughout the department for another 90 days and 125 days". I say we need explanations. That is not correct. I could go on to every section of this bill.
I beg the member to vote for us, vote on this motion so that we can get into committee and debate these questions and return with a bill, with a response that has been properly studied by all of us who have an interest in this bill.

I rise on a point of order, Mr. Speaker. I think we have all been impressed not only with the thoughts that have been expressed by the member for Ottawa-Vanier but with his long experience as a member of this House and as chairman of the Standing Committee on Public Accounts.
He has indicated that he has a number of other points that he could address. I wonder if there might be unanimous consent to give him an additional 20 minutes so that he can continue to share his wisdom with the House.
