Mr. Speaker, I wish to participate in the debate on Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada.
It is interesting that the government would see fit to bring in legislation at this time and to hear members of the government's side of the House tell us how fair it is going to be for the public servants of Canada and how efficient it will be.
We saw how fair this government was last summer when the Public Service Alliance was coming to the government with its concerns. We saw close to 100,000 out here on the front lawns and how this government reacted.
Before I start on the bill, it would be appropriate to give a little history of what this government has done

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
over the last seven years with regard to public servants. Since the Mulroney government came to power just over seven years ago, we have seen an unprecedented attack on government services. It has passed legislation which cuts funding for health care, education, housing, unemployment insurance, job creation, the CBC and VIA Rail. It has given us eight more senators. He found some money for eight more senators to be able to get a piece of legislation through the Senate. It increased the salaries of bureaucrats by tens of thousand dollars each, including a massive raise for the Governor of the Bank of Canada, Mr. John Crow.
We are not talking about efficiency. We are not talking about fairness to the Public Service people. I have talked to the Professional Institute of Public Servants. Yes, there are some in those departments who would be only too happy to see this piece of legislation go through and some of the powers they would have.
I have many public servants in my riding. I have three national parks: Kootenay National Park, Yoho National Park and Glacier National Park. People are out working the highways with knowledge of what is going on. What this bill will do is take away the initiative and the pride they have in their jobs.
We also have joined highways of provincial jurisdiction that are now contracted out. I want to say to this House that I have seen the difference between privatization and our public sector workers through PSAC on our park roads. You can notice this immediately when you leave the federal park road and hit the provincial road that is now under private enterprise.
I have seen the kind of jockeying that takes place when it comes to contracts and how these are dished out. When I hear the member from the Liberal Party asking to have this bill hoisted for a six-month period, I am in full agreement. It is time this government started to listen to some of the people and let the opposition side of the House have some input into the kind of legislation that it is bringing forward. The kind of legislation that it is bringing forward is not going to address the needs of the Canadian people. We have seen that before. We have seen where this government stays in the polls at this time. It is down to 12 per cent. Is it any wonder that this government is down 12 per cent in the polls?
I talk to public servants in my riding and they tell me about the conduct of what is going on and how the morale has changed. When I talk to the people in the income tax department, in the unemployment insurance department, people involved in the highways, the parks or in customs throughout my area, I begin to realize exactly how these people are being treated and why the Canadian people feel the way they do toward governments.
They reflect what the government is doing to them and to the opposition members as well. It is wrong. These people have a great deal of pride in the work they cany out. They are very efficient in their work and how they conduct themselves. They are literally being throttled by this government with its policies and programs. Their grievances have built up through the years. These have not been processed and have not been put through the system in an efficient manner because this government does not believe in it.
It believes in giving them certification as a union to negotiate in good faith and then it treats them like it did last summer, passing back-to-work legislation without any mediation.
Then the member on the other side gets up and asks the member if he thinks this government is going to be fairer. In fact, his actual words were: "Flexibility to be fairer to our public servants". Can you imagine?
I do not know where he gets the audacity to come into this House and say they want to be more flexible because they are going to be fairer. I want to say to you, Mr. Speaker, it is a matter of trust.
The Public Service Alliance does not trust this government. The people of Canada do not trust this government. The opposition does not trust this government. The Liberal amendment asks for a six-month hoist on this bill. It recommends bringing in some of those PSAC representatives and those experts they have brought forward. Let us bring in the opposition side of the House and sit down and go over this bill. Let us bring about some changes.
We all know that some changes are needed, but let us bring in some changes that are going to be for the benefit of all Canadians and not for the benefit of the agenda of this government.
February 10, 1992

I would like to go over some of the concerns. Once again, the Tory government is going after workers in the public sector under the guise of reform. The rights of workers in the federal Public Service are being undermined. There is no question about that because that is what this bill is all about.
The government says it wants to establish a more creative, innovative, service oriented Public Service. In reality it wants to impose from the top down this vision regardless of the needs and the inputs of the workers.
I worked for CP Rail for 40 years and I saw an employer who I thought was callous. But I want to tell you that we used to operate those trains and leave that division. They knew that train was in our possession, and they respected that we were going to run those millions of dollars worth of trains across the country. They gave us some authority and some respect.
If this government did the same to our public servants and gave them the respect and dignity they need, we would see a much better response from those workers. We would see a much better attitude across Canada in what these people are trying to perform and how they are trying to carry out their duties.
That is the kind of legislation we should be looking at. If we want to really address the problem, we should be looking at some kind of communication among those workers, the government and management, and bring about the kind of legislation that is going to best address the system.
We talk about competitiveness in the work place. I will tell you that the Japanese have certainly shown us how to do it. They have been doing it for about 10 to 15 years, and this government still has not caught on to the idea that it better sit down with its workers, the people who are carrying out the every day chores and the every day agreements that are laid out and the process of that.
It better sit down with them and get the co-operation of those people, their managers and the various people, to bring about the kind of changes we need. It is not going to get it by forcing this kind of legislation through the House of Commons.
Many in the Professional Institute of Public Servants are waiting with their hands folded over for the authority that this new PS 2000 is going to give them to make the
Government Orders
kinds of decisions and changes they want. They are waiting for the extra power they seem to think they are going to have, but it will be short-lived.
It will be short-lived because this government will give them that authority until it decides it is time to make its patronage or other appointments. Those people will eventually find themselves down there with the other ones in the long run. I say to those who think there is something in this bill for them that they are sadly mistaken because it is not there at the present time.
The Public Service Alliance people, the workers who are out there trying to maintain their jobs and do their work, have had their fill of this government. They are telling this government in no uncertain terms that they are waiting for the day this government is out of power so they can deal with a government which will sit down and listen to some of their concerns.
I do not care whether you are dealing with public servants, labour in the private sector or whatever, you must have co-operation. This government does not seem to understand that you have got to have the co-operation of the people you hire and put in those places to work for you. Across Canada, this vast nation, there are public servants carrying out the regulations passed here in the House of Commons. This government does not give them the dignity nor the respect of trying to bring about that kind of co-ordination, co-operation between governments and the workers and the official staff and the workers. If this government thinks this response will do what it thinks it will do, it is sadly mistaken.
I would like to put on the record what some of the unions have to say. Contractors are taking the government for a ride. If it breaks down again, they will get more business. Members of the Calgary weather office produced a specialized snow forecast for the city of Calgary and the Ministry of Transport runway crews. MOT was not charged anything for this as it is an intergovernmental project, but the city of Calgary was charged $600 per month. In the name of privatization, the government has said that this cannot be done anymore. Now the cities pay 10 times as much for a firm in St. Louis to do it.
MOT has gone on to the St. Louis firm for the same reasons. The cost of total wages has been drastically reduced simply by contracting out services previously

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
performed by indeterminate employees at a high cost to the employer and a lower standard.
Reducing the number of employees has reduced costs, but has increased the workload of those remaining, contributing to low morale or no opportunity for job advancement and the ever-increasing fear that tomorrow they may not have a job. Is that the message you want to get out to your workers? Are those the kinds of opportunities you are telling these people about, that under the merit system they are going to be able to get their promotions? That is absolute nonsense, Mr. Speaker. There is no way the average worker doing his or her job is going to have any recognition or any further protection under this piece of legislation.
The bill is not about reform, innovation or creativity. It is about the further emasculation of the Public Service and rights of workers. This bill allows the government to continue to contract out work. The government now spends in excess of $5 billion on contracting out. There is no accounting for the expenditure and no study of the cost-effectiveness of the contracting out.
Imagine, there is no study of the effectiveness of it. It reminds me of a provincial highway. When I leave federal park roads which have been nicely ploughed and I hit the private sector roads in British Columbia which have been contracted out, I can sure tell the difference and so can every person driving an automobile.
It provides the mechanism for increased devolution of managerial responsibility and accountability. It attacks the job security of Public Service sector workers. The bill does not addresses the serious problem of low morale in the Public Service. Does it address that? No. Does it address the deterioration of the service to the public? No. Is it to modernize the collective bargaining process? The Alliance still will not be able to bargain issues of classification and staffing levels. Again, it is a matter of trust. Where the government has said in the past that it would ensure that it would have these opportunities, it is taking it away.
What do the workers want? They suggested making staffing classification and deployment of staff bargain-able. That is not too much to ask. They would like an adjustment process to hear grievances on the above. If you have a grievance, surely to goodness it should be
heard and it should be heard in a reasonable period of time. If you want to speed up and have an effective Public Service, for goodness sakes, do not leave grievances hanging out there until they create the kind of atmosphere which we have had. They want an end to contracting out. Is that too much to ask if your people are doing effective work and carrying out the work? If you are trying to bring about fairness to these workers, that is not too much to ask.
I could go on and on, but I know the government is not going to listen. It does have a majority. It will do the same with this piece of legislation as it did with the back-to-work legislation that it imposed on these workers by bringing in its heavy hand, not even bringing about discussions or normal process of legislation when it comes to back-to-work legislation. No other government, including the Liberals, ever brought back-to-work legislation into this House without first going to mediation. That is the type of heavy-handed attitude that this government has toward its workers.
For this government to come and say now that this piece of legislation is going to help those workers and that it is doing it to bring about a fairer contract for these workers, I say is ludicrous. It is a matter of trust. This government cannot be trusted and we cannot support this piece of legislation.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend indicates that this government cannot be trusted and indicates that this government does not listen. I would remind him that the people of Canada in 1988 and before that, in 1984, had an opportunity to determine who best was qualified and in whom the people of Canada wished to entrust the governance of this nation. I would remind him that they twice chose the government of Brian Mulroney and the Progressive Conservative Party and twice elected the NDP not even as the Official Opposition, but as a rump within this Parliament. They might well remember that.
I am sure my hon. friend has ingratiated himself to his NDP colleagues in the labour movement and in the leadership of the labour movement, and I am sure Mr. Daryl Bean undoubtedly would have really enjoyed my hon. friend's remarks, but I think there is a certain dissidence between what he says and reality and the
February 10, 1992

facts. The facts are that Public Service 2000, the white paper, was an extremely comprehensive process of consultation. All of the Public Service sector unions were involved very extensively in the 10 task forces and in making presentations to the 10 task forces and were consulted at great length. The presentation of the white paper was delayed, I might remind my hon. friend, in order that extensive consultation could take place with the public sector unions. Changes were made, changes that manifest themselves in this eminently reasonable legislation in order to accommodate what the members of the Public Service themselves felt, through their organizations, should be there. I would remind him of that.
My hon. friend talks about contracting out and cites as the definitive authority on contracting out the very trade unions which have a vested interest against contracting out. I agree with my hon. friend that there should be very careful scrutiny of the effectiveness of contracting out, but it should be done by objective authority. We should not just automatically take the point of view of one side in that issue that has an unequivocally vested interest.
Finally, I would remind my hon. friend that the function of the Public Service of Canada is not to create or provide employment. It is to provide services to the people of Canada that through their elected representatives it was determined should be established.
I would remind my hon. friend that those services should be provided effectively, not only from the point of view of the services themselves, but efficiently in terms of the interests of the public, who after all are also taxpayers. If those services can be more effectively performed on behalf of the public through contracting out, then it should be done on that basis. In the same way, agencies of the government should not exist in perpetuity, and if tasks can be performed in the private sector more efficiently and do not have to be performed to meet public service needs through the government running the operation, then privatization is indeed appropriate.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased that the member has asked me a few questions. The fact of the matter is that the process leading up to the PS 2000 report was one that saw the concerns of the workers, as
Government Orders
expressed through PSAC and the Professional Institute of the Public Service, ignored.
Therefore, for you to talk about a matter of trust in 1988, I want to say that the Prime Minister stood up in 1988 and told the Canadian people that our social programs were a matter of trust and he would ensure that they were kept. He even referred to his mother and said: "Even my mother would not support me if I were to deviate from this".
And she doesn't.

Now we find out that they are not a sacred trust to this government any more.
I want to say to the member that the Canadian people do not trust this government. Yes, we are talking about service, and in order to have good service you must have public servants and people who know what the programs are, what the government is trying to do, and co-operate with the government in order to carry them out. If you do not have this in this government or other groups, you will never have an efficient work force.
I say again, this piece of legislation is going to do some more harm. It is a matter of trust, and neither the Canadian people nor the workers nor anyone trusts this government at this time.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask my colleague from Kootenay East a question.
I know that along with myself he shares a number of federal government services. Being next-door neighbours, as it were, I am also acquainted with the fact that he has held considerable discussions with members of the Public Service Alliance and other employees of the federal government within his own area. Many of them work in national parks, both within his constituency and mine. In fact my colleague is a former mayor of one of the major communities in my own constituency. It is one of those vagaries of redistribution that we sometimes switch communities.
I do know that he has held some consultations, and I wonder, arising from those conversations, just what appreciation he has developed of the degree of consultation that took place with the government over the last two years on PS 2000 and other initiatives related to the bill before us, and what degree of confidence those

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
employees within his constituency have as to the legitimacy of that whole consultative experience.

I would like to thank my colleague from Kootenay West. He is absolutely right. There have been small meetings throughout my riding, and I believe some over into his area, with regard to the PS 2000 and how it is going to affect workers. I was not able to attend some of those meetings, but I have copies of the minutes of the discussions they have had.
Some things that came out of those meetings regard loyalty and public relations. They feel they have been betrayed by this government. They had a loyalty to this government, as to all governments, to perform their duties well.
Other comments they made are similar to what I said with regard to appointing eight new senators to fulfil and to push a bill through the House and through the Senate, at the same time that they were forcing the public servants out on strike, at the same time that they were out on strike allowing the Governor of the Bank of Canada to have his wages increased by almost double.
Those were the kinds of things where they feel betrayed by this government. They recognize that changes must be made with regard to their agreements and how they can be streamlined. They are prepared to put in their input and hopefully have some say along with their managerial people.
I meet with the superintendents in my national park and I talk to them about what is going on. They rely on those workers who are out there doing the everyday work, and they have a fairly good working relationship with those people. When it comes to the top areas and how the programs are initiated, the people feel that they are being ignored. They feel that they have very poor public relations through that system. Even though they belong to trade unions and try to bring about their efforts, they feel frustrated. They feel they have been neglected.
I think they are just patiently waiting for an opportunity to throw this government out of office. I guess that is as much as I can say at this time.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased after a couple of warm-ups to now
have an opportunity to participate in this debate. I think we should remind ourselves that Public Service 2000 was a multi-year program of changes to internal administrative rules and regulations designed to make the Public Service more flexible, streamlined, and better equipped to concentrate its attention on providing services to the Canadian public. That is what the Public Service is all about.
Bill C-26, the Public Service Reform Act, is an essential part of PS 2000. It will streamline outmoded provisions regarding collective bargaining, staffing, human resources management, and the disposal of surplus assets.
Bill C-26 reaffirms the mandate of the Public Service Commission as the agent of Parliament charged with the responsibility for protecting the merit principle. In particular, the commission will maintain its role to assess merit with respect to recruitment to the Public Service and promotions to higher level duties. The commission will be authorized to define by regulation what constitutes promotion.
Back in the early 1900s, when Canada's civil service legislation was first being developed, the basic reason for requiring that appointments be made on the basis of merit was to prevent political patronage. Every government since that date, including this one, has supported the merit principle. As Bill C-26 demonstrates, this government continues to support that principle.
Merit is the recruitment of the best qualified candidate and promotion of the best qualified. This concept remains at the centre of the values of the Public Service Employment Act. To suggest otherwise, as has been done in this debate, is not to read this bill. Section 10 of the present act remains as it is.
Members who have been part of a large organization are only too well aware that organization charts are usually out of date on the day they are distributed. In today's world, jobs change over short periods to meet ever-changing requirements. The speed of technological change is dramatic. For example, the distribution of micro-computers in the Public Service increased from
10,000	in 1987 to 180,000 last year.
Public servants throughout their careers must continuously adapt through training and skills enhancement. In this environment, it would be short-sighted to recruit young people to meet only the requirements of their first
February 10, 1992

job in the Public Service. New recruits must also demonstrate that they can contribute to the needs of Canada's Public Service as they evolve over time. They must be able to show that they are the best qualified and that they have the potential to respond to new social challenges, to meet the needs for services of an increasingly varied public, and to consult widely with stakeholders in a truly client oriented fashion.
For these reasons the bill adds a new basis for selection according to merit in very specific circumstances.
The commission will be able to prescribe standards not only with respect to a particular position but also with respect to "present and future needs of the Public Service". In the old days it was relatively simple to define a job, to select standards needed to meet the requirements of that job, and to recruit by means of a competition the best person qualified to do the job.
I am pleased to see in this bill, among other things, that for the first time in legislation there will be provision for the establishment of employment equity, although we have had for some time employment equity programs.
I refer to new section 5.1, which says:
On the request of the Treasury Board, the Commission may provide for the administration and operation of programs for the improvement of employment and career opportunities in the Public Service for disadvantaged persons or groups of persons, including those that are disadvantaged by reason of race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, sex, age or mental or physical disability.
I think it is very important that this provision be included in an explicit manner. There has been suggestion from time to time that employment equity is in fact a disincentive or indeed is an inherent form of discrimination. It is important to note that this is not at all what employment equity is. What this bill really is focusing on is the concept of providing fair criteria for decision making in terms of hiring and promotion. When we talk about people's qualifications for the job, a standard may be set of what is in fact a qualification for a position.
At the same time it is important that employer groups, obviously headed by the government, should have some kind of reflection of the community they are intended to serve. Whether we like to admit it or not, we have had for many centuries systemic discrimination in the way
Government Orders
large organisms or institutions like governments function.
If we can look, for example, in a statistical way at the people who are employed in large organisms, be it the Government of Canada or indeed the telephone company, large retail chains, oil companies or anything else, we should see some kind of balance, not only in the proportions of people of different groups that exist within that organism, but indeed they should be represented fairly at the different levels.
Employment equity is a concept that gives promotion advantage or hiring advantage not to people who are not qualified, because it only allows for the promotion of people who are in fact qualified, but gives preference from among qualified candidates to candidates from the under-represented group.
This is something that we as Canadians should applaud and welcome to ensure that the institutions of our society-and none is more basic than the Public Service of Canada-have fair representation of all peoples and all Canadians within our Public Service. The reality is that has not always been the case.
I applaud the explicit reference there. I might mention that there have been for some time de facto programs carried out through the Public Service and through Treasury Board. I refer to things like the Access Program, the Visible Minority Employment Program, the Northern Careers Program, the National Indigenous Development Program and OPTION, the non-traditional occupations program for women. Of course these programs have been very successful and have touched directly many hundreds of Canadians involved in the Public Service of Canada. I think it is important that we upfront the commitment of the Government of Canada to this very important priority.
There are many instances when it makes more sense to appoint a person who can demonstrate that he or she meets the standard of competence established by the Public Service Commission. I would like to give members present here today some realistic examples, not to be confused with some of the distorted examples I heard reference to earlier, where this would be a preferable route for us to take.
There are many training and apprenticeship programs taking place in the Public Service. As employees prog-

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
ress through various stages of their training they become competent to meet the requirements of the next level.
It would seem reasonable to make such appointments not on a competitive basis but on a demonstrated proof that the employee has reached a certain level of competence, for example by successfully passing a test or completing a certain number of hours of on-the-job training. It should be remembered that an assessment of merit was applied when the employee entered the program.
The point made is that when the Public Service of Canada goes out to recruit people to work for the Canadian public, if it wants the best possible candidates it is competing with industry.
When young people are looking for job opportunities, they are going to ask: "What is in it for me in the future?" It is not just a matter of asking: "What job am I going to have today, but where am I going to be five years or ten years from now?" Well, if they go with General Motors or with Eaton's or Imperial Oil, they have some reasonable expectation of how they are going to progress through the system.
At the same time when the employer, be it the Government of Canada or somebody else invests in an employee to see that he or she has the specialized training in order to progress through the system, it only makes sense that there should be a reasonable expectation, both on the part of the employee and on the part of the employer, that that person is in fact going to progress through the system.
Another case where this approach would be justified is where an employee's job has been reclassified to a higher level. If the employee has consistently demonstrated competence in fulfilling the job requirements, then he or she should be appointed without an extensive and costly-and I stress costly-staffing exercise involving a comparison with all potential candidates for the position.
If somebody is doing the job, the job has been reclassified, they are doing the job well and they are doing it effectively, the odds are that they should be allowed to continue in that position. Simply because it is being reclassified, it does not make sense to go to the tremendous expense of disrupting the whole process with a competition in that case.
I believe members will realize that the principle of merit never ruled out other principles of good management theory. The Canadian political system also values qualities such as efficiency, effectiveness, sensitivity and equality of opportunity.
The Public Service 2000 white paper noted that the executive has responsibility for management of resources made available to it by Parliament. For this reason Bill C-26 provides that deployments should be the responsibility of management.
What are deployments? They will be basically the same as a lateral transfer except they will not be an appointment. They will be under the control of the deputy minister who will be guided by policies and guidelines approved by the Treasury Board.
Managers need to be able to ensure that jobs get done when they need to get done. The staffing system should be flexible enough to permit a manager and an employee to agree that the employee should assume the responsibilities of a new position if it is at the same level as the employee's current position.
Deployments will only occur with the consent of the employee in most instances. Where an employee thinks that there has been an abuse of authority with respect to a deployment, he or she will have the right to seek redress including third party investigation.
The concept of deployment does not violate the principle of merit. Deployments will benefit individual public servants, in particular those who wish to expand their career opportunities by taking lateral transfers to jobs which present new challenges and which require the learning of new skills.
There was a suggestion put, I believe by the hon. member for Scarborough-Rouge River, to the effect that this bill did not acknowledge the recommendation of the Standing Committee on Public Accounts with respect to the issue of disclosure. I would say that to legislate along the lines previously suggested by the Standing Committee on Public Accounts might not respond to every situation. Let me illustrate.
There have been calls by the Standing Committee on Public Accounts to make nothing introduceable in an appeal hearing unless previously disclosed. What if information came to an employee that would support his or her case after the disclosure step had been completed and the appeal hearing had started? It could in fact work to the disadvantage of the employee.
I would say as well that it is the practice within the Public Service in handling appeals to make sure that the
February 10, 1992

appellant is aware of the full circumstances under which the decision was made.
I wish to emphasize that these relatively modest changes to the current law regarding staffing provide for a system of checks and balances. The appeal system remains relatively unchanged.
The powers of the Public Service Commission to ensure the delegated authorities to departments are properly exercised are greatly enhanced.
I commend the bill to all members for its urgent passing in the interest of Canadians, but also in the interest of Canadian public servants.

Mr. Speaker, I listened attentively to the remarks of the member from South Shore.
I want to come back to the debate he and I had a few minutes ago on the merit principle because he alluded to it. I want to make it clear there is a conditional obligation now for the Public Service Commission not only to look but it is an obligation to describe who is the best candidate to do the job. But there will be an assessment made now, and I take it that the member understands that, according to standards to be set by the commission.
In my view, this will bring about a situation where, instead of ranking employees according to the merit of each employee and comparing them to find the most qualified, the principle of hiring the most qualified will now be changed, modified or replaced by the principle of hiring a, I underline a, qualified person, not the most qualified. That is the point I want to make with the member.
The Public Service Commission which has been the watch-dog over the merit principle is going to become the lap-dog, not the watch-dog. That is what bothers me.
I want to ask the hon. member, being a member of the government, does he have any idea of the standards that are going to be set, the rules and regulations that are going to be in place? How is the commission going to reconcile merit on the basis of selecting the best to do the job with the new proposal, not the best among equals, but in someone's opinion one of those who is best qualified?
Government Orders
I do not understand why we want to dilute the Public Service Commission's mandate. I do not understand why at this time the government endorses such a move. I would like to have some explanations from the member as to why he does.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
I would certainly like to respond to my hon. friend. I think it is important to recognize that the merit principle, as indicated in section 10 of the act remains in place and is indeed the basis for hiring decisions and promotion decisions within the Public Service.
What subsection 10(2) is designed to do is to deal with fairly specific circumstances. What we are dealing with here are situations where the circumstances effectively dictate the candidate for appointment.
Some examples would be: where no other candidate can possibly meet the requirements of the duties, such as the case with scientific researchers in a specialized field of research who are being promoted in recognition of their record of contribution in the field; or where an appointment is based on the achievements of an individual, as is the case of persons who are in training, development and apprenticeship programs who have successfully completed their training requirements and are ready for promotion, the example I referred to in my general remarks; or where candidates would otherwise be competing for their own positions, as in the case where an employee's position has been reclassified.
In addition, we would foresee using this authority to deal sensitively and compassionately with situations where an employee has been required by circumstances to accept a lower level job and has found an opportunity to be reinstated at the higher level. This may be the case where an employee has had to relocate in order to obtain medical treatment for a family member or to assist an aging parent. In these circumstances we would wish to provide for a manager to appoint the employee when a position at the former level for which the employee is qualified becomes available.
The provisions of subsection 10(2) will give the PSC the flexibility to deal with these circumstances and to adapt to new circumstances as the nature of Public Service employment changes in response to the changing needs of the Canadian people.

February 10,1992
Government Orders

I go on to another point that the hon. member raised in his speech and that is employment equity.
Adding a clause on employment equity programs that are indeed initiated at the whim of Treasury Board and may be, I underline the words may be, implemented by the commission seems to me more of a public relations exercise than anything else, rather than a genuine effort to achieve fair representation for employment equity among the target groups.
It's a diversion tactic.

Yes, it is a diversion tactic. I ask the member in all honesty: Where does he see the great opening here, the opening of the heart to people to allow for a real good and effective employment equity program? I do not see it in that bill. He has tended to take it as a very forward movement. I would like him to give me more details on that.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
I would be pleased to respond to my hon. friend. He refers to it as programs that exist at a whim. I see it rather as a further commitment of the government, a commitment based on the eight years during which these programs have in fact been in place.
I would suggest to him, for example with respect to the access program that it provides on-the-job training for persons with disabilities who require additional work experience to compete equitably for positions in the Public Service. Since 1983, there have been 1,228 participants. Is it a whim to those 1,228 people who have participated in this program, 1,056 of whom completed the program and over 70 per cent of whom are today members of the Public Service?
The visibility minority employment program provides incentives to departments to recruit members of visible minority groups from outside the Public Service. There have been 426 Canadians who have participated in this program since it was established by this government in
1986.	Three hundred have completed the program and 285 of them have been appointed to positions in the Public Service, 86 per cent of these at the officer level.
The northern careers program is another example of a substantive program which is responsible for increasing the representation of aboriginal peoples in the federal government in the Yukon and Northwest Territories through on-the-job and formal training. Since it was
established in 1983, 372 persons have taken part in this program.
These are just examples. If my hon. friend would like, I could give him more.
I think the point has been made that there is a commitment by the Government of Canada and I might say not just the current Government of Canada, but indeed the previous Government of Canada.
I believe all Canadians have an expectation that the Government of Canada will lead and will meet its commitments in this regard.
I would hope all members of Parliament would applaud and be encouraged by this further step, perhaps a small step, but this further step with the inclusion of section 5(1) into Bill C-26; yet another reason in my judgment why this bill should be expeditiously passed by this House.

Mr. Speaker, I am happy to have an opportunity to speak on this bill. We are speaking about probably one of the greatest treasures this country has, namely its public servants, men and women who look after every aspect of serving the people of this nation from coast to coast.
So often I think we take this Public Service for granted. We do not realize that if we are in an urban area we may think of the Public Service as being the employment office or we might think of it as the department of health, or maybe the secretary of state or maybe the passport office. We do not realize that this Public Service is an institution of 250,000 men and women. Many thousands are employed in the Department of National Defence. We are covering every service here. Agriculture Canada has inspection agencies all across the country that make sure the quality of food and the agricultural processes and operations are looked after. We are talking about our first line service to the public in terms of the unemployment offices and customs and excise people. When tourists and business people come to this country, the first people they meet, quite often, are the customs officers at our 30 or 40 airports across the nation. We are talking about the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. We are talking about the embassies all over the world.
We are talking about a bill today that touches the lives of people who have committed themselves more to a vocation than to a job. We are talking about people who


Jj5vi

are concerned about their incomes but there is a certain pride in working for the Government of Canada.
I do not think anybody would refute the fact that it would be a great thrill to work for an IBM or a General Motors or a McDonald's or Magna or whatever, but I bet you nine out of ten Canadians, if they had an opportunity to work for the Government of Canada serving the people and the nation, would take that opportunity.
Quite frankly, what I see here from the government side is this lean, mean machine approach to the human side of this government. It seems to me that it has brought many of the principles of business to running the Public Service when in fact those principles do not apply here.
I come from a business background myself. I have worked in small businesses, medium sized businesses and larger businesses. In business there tends to be: "What will our earnings be per share per quarter?" That tends to be our focus. We are concerned about our employee relations but the bottom line of the Public Service is a totally different operation than business. It is the business of serving people. You cannot analyse it in the same way.
I listened to the previous speaker from South Shore. He talked about streamlining as you would talk about constructing machinery on an assembly line in a factory. I really think he is missing a very important point here.
The spirit of the Public Service of Canada is one of the most important things that we must address and, quite frankly, because of the actions of this government over the last few years, the Public Service has become shell-shocked.
My riding does not have very many public servants. Whether I win or lose in the next election has nothing to do with the Public Service of Canada. I might have four or five public servants in my riding. I do know that my constituents care about the quality of service that the public servants in and around my riding give to them right now because of the way this government has shell-shocked the Public Service. This government, in the last few years, has dismantled agency after agency. It has cut man-years out of department after department. In this sort of possessed focus on reducing the deficit and the debt, the government has actually created an inverse problem. I will be very specific. In the city of Toronto they have cut the man-years of the department of
Government Orders
immigration to a point where not only have we affected the image and the reputation of that Public Service, which has been one of the most respected Public Services in the world for many years, because of its lack of ability to really deliver the kind of services that should be given to the public, but they have also caused a further cost to the treasury.
Again I said I would be very specific. In Toronto right now we have a backlog of refugees. I believe it is close to
50,000.1 might be off by 2,000 or 3,000 but that is not the point. It is such a backlog because of the lack of support in the Public Service. In the last two years it has cost the taxpayers of Canada, just in the city of Toronto alone, close to $3 billion to look after the refugee backlog.
In the name of efficiency and streamlining and cutting the Public Service we have actually added another $3 billion to the deficit and ultimately, the national debt of this country not to mention the wear and the tear on the morale of the public servants.
I could go on and on. I visited many embassies in the last couple of years and have talked to public servants. In some places we have so constricted the actions of public servants that they are even short of photocopiers. In a place like Hong Kong, where there are many entrepreneurial people who want to come to Canada, to invest their money here, invest in factories which will help keep Canadians employed, but because we have constricted the Public Service so much, we cannot even get some of the jobs done we are trying to do.
Therefore, when the Public Service feels this shellshock after shell-shock, this dismantling of the national government which has been going on for the last six years, a couple of things happen. Aside from the absolute natural breakdown of morale and spirit, we also develop a lack of trust. There is nothing more difficult to repair than a lack of trust.
Even if the national government was to present a proposal of change to the Public Service of Canada, it comes with tremendous suspicion. That is one of the reasons why we on this side of the House are supporting the amendment of my colleague for Ottawa West that Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada, be

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
not now read a second time but that it be read a second time this day six months hence.
We have a crisis of confidence in this country in every sector, in every region. There is no greater opportunity in the approach and in the challenge of rebuilding the national unity of this country than with a motivated, inspired, committed public service in every department of this government.
Let us just refer to the province of Quebec. Right now we are going through tremendous difficulty in terms of confidence and in terms of the relationship Quebec has with the rest of Canada. We have close to 125,000 public servants on the payroll of the Government of Canada to serve the people in the province of Quebec. What kind of a message are they motivated to send out, day in and day out, when they touch literally millions of Quebecers, when they see the nation's boardroom treating them in such a way that their morale is low, when they feel they are not being treated fairly?
I feel this is an asset that the minister responsible for national unity could not lean on because the morale is so low. If I were the minister responsible for national unity, I would certainly like to be able to count on the 125,000 men and women in the province of Quebec to go out and explain to their communities and all over the province the goods, services and programs that the Government of Canada is providing to the citizens of Quebec.
If that force is being crushed, is not being respected and is not being treated fairly well, it is no different than any other business or environment. It is not that we will not get work, but the quality of that work will not be as good as a force that is motivated.
I really feel strongly about this bill, not just in terms of the general service to the public but also in terms of the federal presence. Quite often, in disadvantaged and remote regions of this country, it is the public servant who really represents the hope, the anchor and the feeling of security of so many Canadians.
Two weeks ago I was in the Middle East on a mission to sell Canadian food. As a member of Parliament, I was so proud to come into the Canadian embassy in Amman, Jordan to see the flag flying and meet the public servants. There was a young student who was travelling. We were chatting about it and he felt the same way. The
response of the public servants was fantastic. That security for the government and the people of Canada is in the ambassadorship of all of our public servants, that feeling we get when we travel abroad and see an embassy. We should try to create that same feeling with our constituents and with the people of Canada when they come into contact with public servants all across our country.
When I first came to this city in 1978, the first person I met was a public servant, Craig Carpenter. It was his pride and his commitment to his vocation which inspired me to continue my work in this city. Quite frankly, when you multiply a force like a Craig Carpenter who was happy to speak for Canada, who was proud of working for the Government of Canada, when you multiply by
500,000	men and women across this country and in all areas of the world, I just do not think that we fully appreciate the positive force that can have on the morale of this country, whether it is the economy or the image of this countiy, whether it is to attract investment or to attract the minds and brains of professional people to come to this country because it is a great place to be.
I know the deficit is important. The debt of this countiy is important. We must be responsible and do what we can to address it. But there is nothing more important than the spirit of the 500,000 men and women who work for this place. They can eliminate waste on their own if they are inspired. They can create efficiency if they are inspired. They can create an attitude of confidence within the people of Canada if they are motivated. The government is so possessed by the deficit that it has this lean, mean machine approach.
When you are serving the public, it is not an earning per share or per quarter approach, and I know that all members of Parliament know that. We go home on weekends and we listen to our constituents. Quite often, even though very few people have respect for members of Parliament today, we know that we work hours and hours that people never see.
I want to say that most of the 500,000 public servants are the same way. They are counting on us to make sure that we treat them the way we would like to be treated.

Quite frankly I think that they are too easily used as a scapegoat, as a battering ram.
I know that there are public servants who like to use the MAD treatment, maximum administrative delay, people who would prefer to push paper and slow down the system rather than have the joy of moving it quickly. We all have examples.
I have cited a couple of examples in this House in which bureaucrats have used the system for whatever reasons they have wanted. Quite frankly there have been times when I judged them not to be the best motivated. Because of the few who have not committed themselves to this life as a vocation, we should not judge the majority.
Seventy or eighty per cent of the public servants of the Government of Canada put out. They work hard and I know members on that side of the House know it. We should not get brainwashed by the complaints that we get from the people or the clientele we have about the few who can sometimes drive us absolutely crazy.
I think that sometimes happens. We all get complaints about public servants who lost a veteran's cheque, messed up a postal service, or there was a contract in a particular department that should have been processed three months ago or a cheque to farmers that should have gone out. We all know that, but we should not condemn the whole system because of those bureaucrats who are possessed by the MAD treatment.
I say to public servants, if any are listening to this debate, that there is one thing as a member of Parliament I have learned in the last three years. There is one thing that frustrates me about the Public Service of Canada. Even though I am defending it here today, I will also debate with the Public Service. If there is one thing that the system can improve on, it is the movement and the processing of paper.
Quite often they are possessed by the MAD treatment, and not possessed by pushing paper through that they could have done today. Quite often they push it off to next week.
To the government, let us cut back on the lean, mean, machine approach and let us see if there is some way we can mobilize the federal presence and the will of the
500,000	people of this country to work for us rather than against us.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to tell my colleague from Broadview-Greenwood that I greatly appreciated his statement in support of federal public servants. It comes from a former businessman who is very knowledgeable about the business world, so I appreciate it tremendously and I thank him.
I would like to ask a question about his statement dealing with morale. I know that he commented on his experience in the private sector and how essential it is to have dedicated people who want to work together. Since 1985, as he knows, federal public servants have been sacrificed on the altar of the budget deficit. The 1985 Wilson budget reduced the number of jobs in the Public Service by 15,000. The Public Service faces budget constraints that you are all aware of, as well as a capping of salary increases. Last year's strike, which literally pitted civil servants against each other, was, in my opinion, unnecessary. In other words, civil servants must now live with a budget freeze that deprives them of funds for training, for the replacement of equipment which is often obsolete, and I agree with them on that, when the workload is increasing, since hiring is frozen. This does not make much sense. As you will recall, Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Finance even dared to brag last year that the size of the Public Service of Canada was the same as in 1973. Mr. Speaker, this is nothing to be proud of, when we know that the population of the country has increased by 20 per cent. It seems to me that the more Canadians there are, the more we should be able to provide adequate services for them. That is a fairly obvious statement.
Mr. Speaker, add to those restrictions the problems caused by the government's bad policies and you will see why morale in the Public Service is zero or below zero. Right now, the morale of public servants is the lowest I have ever seen, and it is a very bad time to undertake a complete reform of the Public Service. This does not seem to me to be a very wise move.
The hon. member mentioned certain contracting-out programs that will, we hear, be increased in the weeks and months to come. This means that we will transfer to managers additional responsibilities to dismiss, suspend and, occasionally, hire people. My question has to do with the accountability mechanisms that are in place. I

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
know that the hon. member worked in the private sector and I ask him: Without a known accountability mechanism, how can we improve the morale of civil servants and ensure that people know who manages what and how? What kind of fairness and justice can we expect in the public system from systems used in the private sector? What can the hon. member tell civil servants about this accountability?

Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank my colleague from Ottawa-Vanier for the question.
First of all on the question of contracting out, there is absolutely no question about the fact that some contracting out is good. The way this government has handled contracting out is sort of a preoccupation. An analysis was done about six months ago and a lot of the contracting out that the government has done has ended up costing the taxpayer almost twice as much as if the government had kept it inside. This is what is going on. In the name of contracting out and in the name of creating efficiency, the exact opposite is happening. That is just fact, and the Department of Supply and Services will verify that.
I do not know who the winners are in this contracting out. It is a terrible thing if you are a public servant and you talk about merit in this bill. If you talk about merit and with the way this government is contracting out, it is contradictory. It is absolutely contradictory. I could be sitting in my department, working along, thinking that I have been doing a good job, and I could be seeing an opportunity to advance in the next six months or eight years. I am working hard and trying to achieve, and then all of a sudden the deputy comes along and contracts out the job that I was working on. What really bums you is when you find out about a year later when the bills come in that the cost of contracting out costs the taxpayer twice as much. That does happen.
I am sure there are some examples in which it is almost the same dollar cost, but you cannot forget the cost of the tear on morale. When you multiply that principle of contracting out in every office, in every system from
coast to coast to coast, I think there is a very bad mistake being made here.
I think in the name of efficiency there are a lot of things going on that are not actually turning out the way they are being stated.

Mr. Speaker, I heard our colleagues in the Official Opposition especially the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier talk about morale in the Public Service. At times his speech was so exaggerated and far-fetched that we had the impression our Public Service was as demoralized as the Soviet public service. I do not think that is the case, however.
If anyone has a morale problem, it should probably be the Liberals, not Public Service employees, would not you agree? A government is a little like a family. When management is strict and the budget is sensibly administered all members of the family are probably happier.
Of course, the Official Opposition would prefer the government to administer the status quo. Mr. Speaker, this is not a status quo government, and we have proved as much in many areas. If we had administered the status quo as the Liberals wanted us to do, the budget would now be $300 billion instead of $155 billion. The deficit would be over $100 billion, instead of having shrunk to $30 billion. I think that is something we should not forget.
In any case, I welcome the opportunity today to say a few words about Bill C-26, which is part of the reform process initiated by Public Service 2000. I think this reform bill will, over a period of several years, have an impact on all internal management rules and thus make the Public Service more flexible, more effective and more service oriented.
The Public Service Reform Act, a vital component of Public Service 2000, will restructure a number of outdated regulations concerning collective bargaining, staffing, human resources management and elimination of surplus goods. There are also some important points in this legislation, including the delegation of authority. The government wants to give more responsibility to people at the base, to all regional managers, who represent a very high percentage of all public servants,
February 10. 1992

Mr. Speaker. As a result of this decentralization, the number of Treasury Board submissions will be reduced by 40 per cent. I think that is quite substantial.
By giving more responsibilities to our regional managers, I think that across the country there will be more opportunities to take advantage of federal involvement. The reduction in the number of management levels is another important aspect. Ten per cent of management category positions will be eliminated. There is also the issue of transfers which will help all public servants acquire more experience in a variety of sectors. We must not forget that once people have had an opportunity to acquire more experience at the same level, they will be in a better position to obtain advancement within the Public Service.
Of course, a reduction in the number of professional groups, which now total 71, will be a significant improvement.
There is also the whole aspect of surplus Crown property. It is so complicated that every department has trouble disposing of its own surplus property. I think that legislation to rationalize this area will enable those officials, deputy ministers and ministers to feel more responsible.
Regionalization is extremely important. Our government has put more emphasis on regional development because we put even more trust in our officials who work in the regions. Most departments, especially Supply and Services Canada, CIDA and the Department of Industry, Science and Technology, are definitely moving towards regionalization. So I think that it is an important step toward the future and towards better service for all our fellow citizens.
For all these reasons, everything our government has done in the past seven years, whether in the economic, social or some other field, has helped us to be the country rated most highly by international organizations. I am thinking of the OECD and the International Monetary Fund, among others. It is not so well known, but I think that our fellow Canadians will gradually realize that what the government has done in each department, especially in terms of the budget, has given us a top national and international rating.

If you allow me, Mr. Speaker, I would like to deal with employment equity at greater length today. For seven years, our government-this year, for example, we will invest $1.8 billion in worker training programs, while respecting the employment equity principle. I think it is good that what our government is doing for all Canadians it is also doing for our Public Service as a whole.
The bill expressly gives the Public Service Commission and Treasury Board authority to carry out programs to improve employment and career opportunities for disadvantaged persons. That is a very good thing, Mr. Speaker, because I think that the Public Service will then better reflect the make-up of Canadian society. In protecting the merit principle as Parliament has instructed it to do, the Public Service Commission will ensure that recruitment outside the Public Service and promotions within it help deputy ministers achieve employment equity in their respective departments.
Treasury Board and the Public Service Commission work closely together to establish special programs to make it easier for members of target groups who do not have equal opportunity to apply for satisfying positions in the Public Service to find employment and be promoted. I am talking about positions that women did not usually occupy before but in which they want to have a real chance to show that they are up to the challenge.
The Public Service Reform Act will enable the Public Service Commission and the departments to ensure that members of the target groups for employment equity can participate in competitions if they meet the established criteria. In its white paper on reform, Public Service 2000 believes that it is necessary to reduce the number of occupational groups in order to simplify the staffing process and to provide better career opportunities.
The new position classification system that has been developed will eliminate all systemic obstacles that prevent members of target groups for employment equity from obtaining a position or a transfer in the Public Service. We will thus have a neutral classification system that takes no account of race, national or ethnic origin, religion, sex, age or mental or physical disability.
Members will no doubt want to know how the new classification system will favour employment equity. According to my information, it will make it possible to eliminate education criteria that are applied systemati-

February 10, 1992
Government Orders
cally and to adapt them to position requirements as established by the Public Service Commission. I understand that this change will mainly affect native people and recent immigrants who are a visible minority and did not attend high school in Canada. It will bring support staff and officers together in one and the same group, general services. This will make it easier for support staff to move up. This group is now called the administrative support category, and women represent 80 per cent of its members.
The elimination of such structural barriers will greatly contribute to do away with the "pink collar" ghetto of women civil servants. Bill C-26 gives legal basis to a deployment system with which managers are to meet more readily the career needs of every employee, in particular those in the employment equity target group.
It will be possible to make deployments between same level positions to allow employees to gain experience and be better qualified for another position or for promotion to the next level. I believe that doing the same job for 35 or 40 years is not the best way to get promoted and to respond successfully to job offers. That is what this part of the bill does.
Deployments will also enable managers to assign civil servants in such a way as to meet the operational needs of government. It must be emphasized that most deployments will require the consent of the employee. This would allow managers to transfer employees who are no longer able to perform jobs they are better suited for.
Certainly, members of this House will agree with me that all these changes are necessary so that the Public Service of Canada can reflect the diversity of the people it serves. I am also convinced that they will agree that the public service legislation should reflect the very best values currently recognized as such in our society. This does not mean everyone should be treated in the same way, but that equal opportunities be offered to everyone by accommodating differences.
This bill shows how much this government is in favour of change. Status quo does not allow us to meet the many national and international challenges facing us, and I am proud of my involvement in this bill.
